Review Text:
It's a really busy restaurant but the staff are kind and patient. I came in with a big group and we ended up being late but the staff were very kind to us. I'm genuinely so grateful that they were accommodating and patient with us. The restaurant is nice, and there's a lot of seating. Service is kind and attentive. There was auto gratuity as we were a big group, and they only accept card for payment. I was able to leave an extra cash tip though- I felt so bad that we were late. 
I ordered the khao soi with curry- you can't adjust spice level for it. It was really good, but I think I prefer the Uptown location more. The beef was a bit tougher compared to the other one. The flavour was great, nice and sweet. It's honestly not too spicy. My boyfriend got the pad see ew, which was also really good. I feel like their food never disappoints. Everyone else at my table enjoyed their food. 
My meal came out to $28 with auto-gratuity. I left feeling full and happy. Definitely recommend.

Had a lovely Sunday night dinner at Pai! I was shocked how big it is! My friends and I walked in without a reservation, I discovered that the restaurant is massive - so there were several tables open. The vibe is quite intimate and cozy.
Servers were very nice. There were lots of staff on the floor. 
Food was delicious! I had the red curry with beef. Rice was perfect - not too sweet, but still nice.
Would highly recommend!

Pai Northern Thai Kitchen offers such a vibrant experience. I loved colorful lighting in the restaurant and the overall vibe at the bar.
We didn't have any reservations and the wait was 30 minutes so hung out at the bar which was a great experience. There's a large variety of drinks that were Toronto themed which caught my attention. They had drinks like "Cherry Trent Jr" and "Scotchie Barnes" which is playful. I chose the Thai Mojito.
Now when it came to dinner, the food was my highlight. I ordered the Green Curry Chicken and I must say that this was probably my favorite Green Curry Chicken ever. One thing that made this different than all others is that it's served in a coconut. The dish itself was tasty but one thing that I particularly loved was scraping the coconut and having a dessert-like experience afterward.
Overall this place was great. Great location, wonderful ambiance, and enthusiastic and knowledgeable staff. I appreciated that they were able to help my colleague who had a gluten and dairy allergy.

We arrived on a weekend for dinner around 4:30pm and the place was packed. There was a long line at the door. Luckily, we got a table after 10min wait. Their convenient location near many theatres and venues makes it a popular option in the area.
The restaurant is spacious with colourful decoration. The music isn't too loud and the noise level is suitable for conversations.
Our server told us their signature dishes are Pad Kra Pao and Khao Soi.
Pad Kra Pao: very good and well-seasoned. We ordered it with crispy pork and it was so delicious! Highly recommend ordering crispy pork to go with this dish.
Khao Soi: presentation was great, so tasty and comforting.
Thai milk tea: good, just the right amount of sweetness
Service was very good despite how busy the restaurant was.
I'd definitely come back to try other dishes.

Dude. I think this is the best Thai restaurant Ive eaten outside of Thailand. Not to be dramatic. My family didn't reserve cuz we are clowns, so we waited 1.5 hours but it was well worth the wait.
The skewers were incredible - juicy and well grilled. The Moo Ping took me back to Thailand.
I got the fish green curry and it was good. The fish was well cooked and fresh. Very well balanced flavors, along with a fun presentation if you care for that. 
However, the Khao Soi (which is my favorite Thai dish ever) was incredible. Deep and rich with flavor (spicy, yet tangy, and sweet), and great portion size. 
The dessert was also incredible - we got the coconut ice cream, and it was so fresh. The toppings also added such a variety of texture.

Chicken wings were to die for.. so good, especially with the chilli sauce. Made my nose run because of the heat. Loved it. 
Khao soi was tasty too. So happy I ordered it. 
Loved this cute restaurant with friendly and attentive staff. 
So glad I took the time out to have lunch here during a work day!

Wowowowow! What an experience! From start to finish, Pai is incredible and I'm so sad I won't be able to revisit it until my next trip to Toronto.
I was warned by multiple people that I'd have to wait in a long line if I wanted to go to Pai without a reservation. I decided to chance it anyway and dropped in as a single around 4pm on a Saturday and I was excited to find out it would only be a 10-15 minute wait. It ended up being just under 10 minutes.
I was seated at the bar at the far end of the deceptively large restaurant. The basement space feels cozy and colourful with lots of decor to look at and a tropical-vibe.
I started things off with a Thai mojito which was a brilliant purple colour. It was a refreshing twist on a classic. For dinner I had a vegetarian version of the Khao Soi which is served with tofu, veggies, and noodles (can be made vegan on request by changing out the egg noodles). This was one of the tastiest dishes I've ever had. The coconut-based broth was bright, flavourful, and perfectly spiced. It was very filling and I was sad that I couldn't take my leftovers with me.

Pai Northern Thai Kitchen has got to be one of my favorite spots in Toronto! I was visiting for the weekend and decided to check it out on a Friday, even though we originally planned to go Saturday. It was a quick walk from our hotel, so we figured why not? Even though the place was packed, we got seated right away at a high-top table. Regular table wait time was 30-45 minutes. It's shared with other groups, but there's still plenty of room to feel comfortable and chat with your friends.
We ordered a ton of food: Thai chicken wings, the Northern Platter, pad see ew with shrimp, green curry, mango sticky rice, a Thai iced tea, and pineapple juice. There were three of us, we knew we overordered, but everything was so good that we somehow managed to finish it all.
The Thai chicken wings were fried with a nice texture, though they weren't super crispy. The sweet sauce drizzled over them was perfect, and I loved that balance of flavors. The Northern Platter was massive and looked almost intimidating--it's definitely shareable and could easily be a meal on its own. It came with sticky rice, pork skewers, northern laab salad, Thai sausages, and these squash fritters. The pork skewers were a highlight; they were so tasty I wanted more. there was a hint of sweetness coated on the pork skewers. The laab salad was really spicy, but even I couldn't stop myself from taking a few bites because it was that good. The Thai sausages had just the right amount of saltiness, and the squash fritters were a fun surprise--I thought they were sweet potato fries at first. 
The pad see ew with shrimp was delicious and not too oily, which is a huge plus. The only bummer was that there were only three shrimp. I didn't even get to try one. Next time, I'd probably go for the chicken or beef instead.
The green curry was amazing. We got it with beef, and it had just the right amount of spice. The beef pieces were a little thick, but overall, the flavors were on point. It was served in a whole coconut, which added this lovely coconut sweetness to the spicy curry. And once we finished, we even scooped out the coconut flesh!
Even though we were stuffed, we couldn't skip dessert. We ordered two mango sticky rice, because it's a must-have at any Thai restaurant. The mango was perfectly ripe and sweet, and the sticky rice, still warm, was drizzled with coconut sauce that made it so comforting. Even if you're full, you have to try it--it's worth it!
Overall, if you're in Toronto, Pai Northern Thai Kitchen is a must-visit. The food is incredible, the atmosphere is always buzzing, and it's totally worth the trip, whether you're a local or just in town for the weekend.

Good thai food overall! Really enjoyed the aesthetic inside and love that they have a waiting area + bar for you to wait at! Came at 6, waited for 15min for table for 4, and had a yummy meal! I think they were p rushed bc they took a while for food + forgot some things but not really a big bother. Kind people, great vibes, enjoyed a classic toronto spot overall :D
Felt on the same level as Soothr in NYC. Wish there were more noodles in Khao Soi, but the flavors were pretty great.

UM what a spot. This was the first food spot I visited when going to Toronto for the first time and I was absolutely not disappointed.
I had heard that it can be difficult to walk in and be seated, but we were able to right away. We ordered a variety of appetizer/table sharers before our main meal - all of the apps were great - from vegetable fried rice to wings, etc.
My main meal was the pad gra prow which was recommended by the kind waitress. It was delicious and had just the right amount of spice (base level). The crunch that was added from the crispy pork was soo tasty.
Definitely understand why this restaurant is acclaimed. The atmosphere was beautiful, calm and relaxing and the food was delicious.
This is the type of restaurant that deserves a Michelin Star.

We ordered:
1. Gaeng Kiaw Wan Green Curry
2. Pad Gra Prow
3. Khao Soi
4. Pad See Ew
5. Mango sticky rice 
6. Coconut sorbet
Solid Thai food. Pad See Ew and pad Gra prow wasn't terribly greasy. White rice was kind of mushy and not the best quality. Meats were dry but flavors were great across the dishes. Coconut sorbet was so creamy and perfect for coconut lovers.
Waiter was very nice and helpful.

I absolutely love this place!!!! 5/5 nothing bad to say.
My friend and I came to PAI on a Friday night with no reservation after seeing all their reservations were booked up. We still went to take our chances with walk in around 7pm and we got a table within 15 mins! It was super busy yet they were still able to seat many of us who walked in.
The place upon entrance looks small but it is MASSIVE inside. The vibes are so good with the decor and the lighting. We both only wanted a main as we needed to leave pretty quickly. Service was super fast and friendly. 
Food:
- Pad Thai with Beef (no chives): 5/5 stars. I was absolutely starving and this was phenomenal. It was not too sweet or sour. It was perfect. Texture was great and portions were pretty big. I could've taken some home if I wanted to but was too hungry.
As we were in a rush, we were able to leave within 45 mins of being there. 5/5!!! Would recommend even if you don't have a reso

Though this is one of the most notoriously difficult restaurants to get a table at in Toronto, the lively ambiance and delicious food make it worth the wait! I tried the Laab Salad with beef, which was very flavourful. 
I'm looking forward to trying more menu items here in the future!

We walked in around 4:30 on a Friday with no reservation and were seated immediately. Definitely go earlier than later because the place filled up while we were there. People were waiting and the bar and there was a line outside the door. 
Place was cute and our server was wonderful! We got a Thai iced tea and a white sangria that came with an entire lychee in it. Drinks were pretty good.
We ordered chicken satay and the squash fritters to start. The satay had good flavor but the squash fritters were out of this world! The batter was light and sweet while the tamarind-based dipping sauce made it refreshing. We had to stop ourselves from eating the entire basket!
We also shared a beef salad and a papaya salad. The beef salad was good, but the meat was cut a bit too thick. I love my spicy food so I got "Thai spicy" for the papaya salad. It was actually not that spicy. The spice was more of a slow burn that built up over time. The rice noodles were a good addition to soak up the juice on the bottom. They were out of shrimp chips that day so we only got pork rinds, which were also very light. The Pad Thai was just Pad Thai. It was good but nothing special. 
I was looking forward to their Thai iced tea gelato served in a young coconut, but it was out so we got the sticky rice instead. Again, it was good, nothing special. I would recommend trying their other desserts instead.

Had an epic meal here last night absolutely loved every single dish I put on the table. We start with a variety of appetizers, including pork and chicken, skewers squash, fritters and they were all amazing. The pork head, a wonderful spicy sweet taste with a little bit of charm from the grill that really made it stand out. Would definitely order that again without hesitation. For entrées, we got pad Thai and pad gra prow. Both of these dishes were absolutely fantastic. Plenty large enough to split with your dining partners. Between the four of us, we had three entrées, eight family style and there's more than enough food. The chicken pant was probably among the best I've ever had great flavor in the sauce and the chicken was nice and tender and delicious.
The star of the show was the coconut sorbet. Served a half coconut comes topped with mango shredded coconut and peanuts, and it was absolutely delible one of the best desserts I've had in a long long time. You're doing a great disservice on yelp reviews for this restaurant and you don't end up dying there. 
On top of the great food, it had a cool funky vibe with the decor the restaurants located in the building and has some community tables and a lot of other quirky seating locations. All the way around.

October 12/2024: Lupper with my Al & Larry/Mary. 
This was a very interesting restaurant. It's in the basement of a building but it was busy as all get out for a later afternoon (4:00pm ish). Bench style seating for the tables and a fast seating. Had our table quickly. 
I had the spring rolls ($14.99) as an appie. They were delicious, crispy & crunchy with a plum dipping sauce. 
My main was Pad See Ew with Chicken ($23.99). This was my first time trying this and it was delicious as well. Very tasty but I should have added MORE spice. 
I also tried a fork full of Mango Slaw ($19.50) & it was very good as well. No complaint about this place except for their lack of menu flexibility. 
It's a do over for me if I'm in the area.
Good Thai food. I bit chaotic for my taste but that is authentic Thai street feel so I can't complain. Staff was good, friendly and attentive. Food came out very social media friendly

Door dashed the Chicken Pad Thai (Medium) and it was very good. It was very good.
I marked the order to include utensils, but it did not. Luckily I had a fork at my hotel so it all worked out.

My husband suggested this Thai restaurant for dinner and I am glad he did.  When we arrived, there was a line out to give our names for dine in.  I also saw that they were on Open Table, but all the reservations were also gone..so we waited in line and after about 10 min we gave our name.  We were told it would take about 20 min so we headed to the bar and got some drinks.
The place is huge..it has several dining rooms and all of them are ample and very nicely laid out.
Our server was really sweet and nice. We opened the menu via the QR code and we decided on the Pad Gra Prow for my husband (basil stir fried with beef over rice) and the Pad See Ew for me (thick rice noodles with chicken).  We started the meal with some chicken satay.  Everything was outstanding...the flavors were probably some of the best I've had outside of Thailand.  It was a winning dining experience.
Large menu with salads, rices, noodles, soups, etc....please check it out next time you are in the area....well worth it....

The vibe at Pai Northern Thai Kitchen was laid back despite it being a Michelin rated restaurant. Hence the hubs said we had to go.
The gaeng hunglay or oxtail curry was really interesting. The rice was adorably wrapped in leaves. You don't often see such a dish at Thai places. But then I've recently learned that northern Thai cuisine is slightly different. The curry had a sweet and sour taste with notes of garlic and ginger. It was flavorful but not overwhelming like sweet and sour soup for instance. All this was set to a mild spice level.
The chicken pad see ew was delicious. This is one of my all time favorite dishes to get. There was a perfect portion of chicken, veggies, and noodles. But the most important thing was the abundant noodles! The veggie stems in this dish was rather bitter, and I couldn't pinpoint what type it was. The chunkiness allowed you to taste the bitterness which slightly turned me off. It turned out that it was Chinese broccoli. Ha! [Yeah. I don't read the full menu to remember.]
Here's a link to their menu: 
https://paitoronto.com/menu/pai-menu#section5
 
The experience is right around 3 or 4 stars for me. Service was on point despite people whizzing about. The decor and atmosphere was fun and chill. Overall it was good food but at a pricey price point.
Was it worth it? To try a Michelin rated restaurant once, yes. To come back and dine again? Probably not for the inflated price due to its hyped up reputation. That's my take on this anyway...

Pai is a restaurant staple of Toronto. I've been a few times and each time I'm impressed with the quality of the food and depth of flavors in each dish.
The restaurant itself has a very hole-in-the-wall feel to it. It doesn't have an elaborate storefront and the inside has a very casual and cozy feel to it. Seating is also limited considering how popular it is, so I recommend trying to go early to get a seat. Arriving at 5pm or earlier gives you a better chance at getting in without a wait.
The service is good but not stellar in my opinion. The staff is friendly enough but can be a bit slow when they get busy.
The amazing food is what you come for! Every dish I've had I've fallen in love it. Each one crafted with elite attention to detail and has a perfect balance of flavors and spices. The Khao Soi is my favorite as the curry is so creamy and so many levels of flavor.
Overall, Pai has some of the tastiest food in Toronto and is a must-go! I've never looked at Thai food the same way after going to Pai and I highly recommend it to anyone and everyone!

Best Hot & Sour Soup Ever
We popped into Pai for dinner, and we were immediately struck by the vibrant, bustling atmosphere. It was a bit overwhelming at first due to how busy and loud it was, but the energy was undeniably lively. Navigating through the various pathways to reach different rooms and our table added to the unique experience.
The highlight of our meal was definitely the hot and sour soup--it was hands down the best I've ever had. The other dishes we shared were decent, though the menu felt somewhat limited in options.
The staff were mostly attentive and friendly, contributing to the overall positive vibe of the place.

In the words of Gen Z, Pai is MID. Pai is on almost every list for Toronto and on the Michelin guide, and there is always a line to get in here. I went on a Friday night during Canada weekend and we got lucky and after getting in line just to get on the waitlist, after waiting 20-30 min, we were seated right away. I am super happy that northern Thai food is getting recognized but I was not impressed with the food. The atmosphere is great - it's vibrant and loud and they have a full cocktail bar. I got a vodka Thai tea cocktail and it was fine. 
The waiter was really lovely and had recommendations, since it was so busy we ordered everything and asked for things to come as they were ready (my sister who I was with is also very impatient at restaurants so it was better for us). 
We ordered: the mago slaw (seasonal) and also a note here, some of the starters are not available until after 4 pm; miang kung  - which is a make yourself wrap, paid thai and PAD GRA PROW, a rice dish with an egg on top. 
I haven't had a decent pad thai in YEARS and this was fine, better than what I've had available, we did ask for a side of hot sauce and cilantro. 
The pad gra prow, was nice, it builds flavor slowly so we thought we didn't like it at first. We did over order, but we were eager to try a lot of the items. 
Overall, if you've had good thai food, you will be disappointed in how hyped this place is - especially since you have to wait in line just to get to the waitlist and they don't answer the phone, I do think there's a email you can write to. The miang kung is fun, and not readily seen a lot of place in the US.

Great vibes here. They play lots of modern rap music and it helps create a very refreshingly young environment. This place is packed too. There is not much seating and my mother and I had to wait as we were walk ins. Not sure if they accept reservations. But I do know they are card only, no cash. 
I was pleasantly surprised to walk in and see the Michelin star rating posted at the front. I knew this had to be good. 
We had a few dishes, everything was HUGE portions, but as a NYer, I was disappointed and did not find the food particularly special. Ive had better from a hole-in-the-wall in a back alley. I thought my pad see ew was over salted and the flavors just did not vary  much from the pad Thai. 
 
I expected more. Also did not feel like the waiter was overly that great. He plopped down plates and I tried to get his attention a few times but was ignored. It was very busy so maybe he was over stimulated by it.

I was EYEING this spot during my travels in Toronto because the line was always around the block and it's on the Michelin Guide. We had to wait in line to put our names down, and they texted us when our table was ready. We went on a Friday night at around 6 PM, and I think it took us about 45 minutes to get seated. I'd say it's a pretty efficient system.
We ordered the Thai Chicken Wings, Papaya Salad, Khao Soi and the Pad Thai. ALL the items were absolute hitters. They were full of flavors and characters but still true to their basics. The papaya salad is one of the hardest dishes to get right because it requires specific grinding of the papaya to give it that perfect texture - Pai's papaya salad was amazing. 
When I come back to Toronto, this spot is one of the firsts I'd visit again.

This might be a silly thing to say, but I didn't think Thai food could get better than my neighborhood places. I stand corrected. 
This place was on the list because it got loads of great reviews. Didn't know it was a Michelin.. contender? Award winner? I'm still not too sure. Either way, it's well deserved.
Vegetarian review:
Pad see ew-  there was something in the sauce. That was the top difference between this dish here and in other places. It was delicious. There was firm tofu (not fried), plenty of veggies, and great noodle texture. The plate was full and filling.
Panang curry: also very good. It was filled with tofu and peas and... a bunch of other stuff. Again, lots of food with a cute rice wrapped in... betel leaf? Flavor was lovely. 
The wait was well worth it, and beware- there is a wait. We arrived at 5.30pm (on a summer Thursday) and hung around outside (in the rain) for about 40min. On the plus- the time frame they gave was very accurate.

Pai is developing a reputation as the best Thai restaurant in Toronto and it is easy to see why. Arriving early in the dinner service on a Friday, we were seated almost immediately. 
The three of us had the Grabong and Moo Ping to start. These were good but not the highlights of the meal. 
The mains were all showstoppers. Chicken Khao Soi, Pad Cha Hett, and Gaeng Massaman with beef. Each more flavorful than the last and bringing a unique palette, from the sweet coconut milk in the Khao Soi to the spice of the Massaman.
I am surprised to see some 4-star reviews here. Perhaps other areas of the extensive menu are less strong? Regardless, everything I ate leads me to HIGHLY recommend Pai.

Arguably one of the best Thai food places you can find in Toronto. PAI has been a go to for me and my friends. It's the place I take people to when they're visiting Toronto. The garbong is a must and you can't go wrong with ordering the khao soi. I am also a sucker for any of their noodle dishes that use rice noodles. Everything is so flavourful but not overly salty. 
The restaurant is down a few stairs and it decorated in a way that makes you feel like you're sitting in the streets of Thailand having a meal.
There is always a line but they have a pretty good system and you get seated pretty promptly. Mind you I still recommend getting reservations or coming right when they opened or on weekdays.

10/10 they deserve a Michelin Star. They're on the Michelin list, and even though we stumbled upon this restaurant while in vacation they got us seated pretty quickly. We waiting in line for about 20 minutes and then were seated. 
This Thai food was good, it's ruined us for any other Thai. Make this a stop! 
The atmosphere was so cozy. The tables seemed close together, but it didn't feel that way when seated.

Went here for lunch on a Saturday early afternoon. Was seated immediately in a super cute indoor space.
The food blew us away!! We tried:
Thai coffee- 5/5 delicious with generous portions 
Khao soi- 5/5 one of the most delicious creamy curries I had, we got this with tofu 
Papaya salad - 5/5 so good with perfect amount of spice. The mini shrimp were an excellent touch
Pad gra pow- 5/5 our FAVORITE- we got with vegan pork and could t even tell it was not real, SO delicious. we got this Thai spicy which was no joke but so good.
Highly recommend!! Consider coming for lunch to avoid long wait!

Amazing must try place in Toronto! There is a line outside to put your name down with the host (30ish min), a wait for a table after putting name down (10-20min), and then wait for food after ordering (10-20min) but it is definitely worth the wait. Food was really good and service was attentive and frequently checked in. Ambiance is nice and unique. 
My party got their khoa soi, green curry, and pad see ew, along with an iced thai tea, mango sticky rice, and coconut mango sorbet for dessert. No bad items on their menu, they are Michelin for a reason.

When the food is good, the wait will be long even on the weekdays.  Seeing this a Michelin Guide restaurant, I knew I have to give this place a try when in town. It took about 1.5 hour for our table to be ready.  
Food - I think we went overboard when we ordered.  I figured if we can't finish we can bring the food back to our hotel since it has a kitchen.  All the food we ordered taste great.  The spice level is just perfect.  This is probably the best Thai Food that I have ever eaten.  
Service - our waitress is great.  Even though she's really busy she still makes time to chat with us and have us some recommendations when we ordered.  
Ambience- it feels like hole in the wall. Nothing fancy.  But it really doesn't matter that much since the food is more important to me.
Overall, this is a very well deserved to be on the Michelin Guide list.  Will be back next time to try other food.

We just visited Thailand a couple months ago and have been thinking about how hard it is to find some specific dishes. Pai definitely delivered with a fun atmosphere with a menu that is hard to choose from. We wanted to try everything! We had the fritters which were flavorful and plentiful as well as a delicious Khao soy and a Penang curry which was thicker than we typically see and so perfect to coat a bed of rice. The coconut sorbet was so fresh and amazing. Everything was delicious and we are only sad that we discovered Pai on our last night in Toronto and could not return!
This food was our favorite in Toronto. It tasted very fresh and flavorful. They told us 20 minutes but only took about 5 to get a table. We got are food quick. Would recommend!

I'm in love with everything from pai. I don't know how they do it but every dish is cooked to perfection. The flavours are all there, it tastes like it's straight out of Thailand. The wok flavour is amazing in the pad see ew- Smokey, has a touch of sourness which brings out the sweetness and savouriness. It just hits all the flavour notes. The Chinese broccoli has a nice crunchy texture opposite to the soft noodles. Will definitely be back to try more!

there's a reason why this place has a Michelin award. All of our meals are so so good and coming from LA, I was not disappointed to pick one of my meals in Toronto to go to this place.
we went in on Sunday afternoon and it was pretty packed, but we only had to wait about 5 to 10 minutes. They will text you when the table is ready.  Place is quite large. I didn't notice that from the outside have a lot of tables for the groups and pairs.
All of the food are awesome and I recommend you to go here if you visit Toronto. The staff are so nice too. I didn't try their tom yum because you can't really customize the spicy level and I can't really eat spicy food.

Simply put, YES!!! This place is the real deal. I'm constantly on the quest for great Thai food, especially northern Thai food like Khao Soi and this place rocks. It's authentic and vibrant. I lost photos unfortunately but images or words can't do their food justice. Service was ok but the reason to go is the food. If you're in Toronto or visiting, it's worth a try. Go early if you don't have a reservation as the line gets long fast, with that said we were able to get a reservation for two with relatively short notice (on the early side).

I came back to Pai after over a year had passed since my last visit.
I ordered the dish I crave and love the most from here: Massaman Curry with Beef. 
Unfortunately, I was disappointed. The flavours were NOT as I had remembered, to the point that I questioned whether the owners/recipe changed? The curry base was a lot more sour. The beef was tough and gamey. The potatoes were slightly undercooked. And the rice completely changed (now sticky rice in a banana leaf; previously jasmine rice which pairs better with the curry). The rice portion size also decreased substantially. 
I used to adore Pai, and consistently enjoyed it for 8+ years. I'm not sure if this was an off day or if their food has permanently changed.

I enjoyed the spring rolls and the Pad See Ew. I like spice and asked for it but I am glad I didn't pour it on. 
The lime, when freshly squeezed on the meal makes it go pop! I thoroughly enjoyed this dish. At first I thought I wanted it spicy but the flavor was fantastic as it was. The lime really made the dish come to life. Pan cut noodles, veggies and I ordered with shrimp but you can get with chicken, beef, etc.
I waited a few days to eat here. I came on a weekday afternoon around 3 and no line. Still full from lunch but no line to wait to get to a table. Full menu, full bar. Service was fast and efficient. Menu is online and QR  odes at the table. No menu handouts.  
Smartly decorated like other Thai restaurants. 
Would highly recommend!! Worth the wait of days and if limited time worth the wait as well.

Very crowded place, so make sure to get there ahead of time or reservation if you can. Food has tons of flavor and seasoned extremely well. Ambiance is alright, unique underground place but it's a little crammed. Had a great experience with noodle dishes, soup, and coconut sorbet. Great selection of appetizers and salad was a great start to the dinner!
As usual the food was good and the lineup outside was long (but pretty fast).   Service was busy but decent.  Annoying menu app did not really work so I could not see any pictures-need paper backup!

If you want some tasty Thai food, rich with flavours, in an atmosphere that works well regardless of who you're dining with, Pai is the spot!
I got a Pad See Ew with shrimp, along with a guava juice drink. The meal portion was filling, and I left the restaurant knowing it's a spot I'd love to return to.

We ended up door dashing to our hotel because they didn't have availability and even through door dash the food was so good, I'm sure eating in person it's probably even better!! We got the basics red curry, pad thai, and crispy chicken and my taste buds were living their best life! Highly recommend - try to get a reservation if you can if not door dash works too :)

We worked up an appetite after seeing cherry blossoms and decided that we were craving Thai food. 
Busy as expected on a Friday, waited only about 20 minutes for a table, had a drink at the bar while waiting. 
Ordered a small Tom yum soup to start very delicious. Pad Thai was chefs kiss delicious also and so was the curry, not a single complaint.
The Scottchie Barnes was a rather small drink (in size and strength).
A little on the expensive side but that's expected with Pai.
Sat at a small table in the middle.

We went here because it was the most popular on Yelp in this area. I learned most popular on yelp doesn't mean the best. We decided to go anyway because we were close. 
I could see why this place is mentioned by Michelin. The vibe cooks. The decor is cute and I could see hanging out here with a group of friends.
This place was also pretty busy. I got oxtail curry because I don't see that in a lot of Thai restaurant menus. The curry had a sour and sweet taste with some notes of ginger and garlic. It was thick and flavorful but not very creamy. It was a mild spice. 
My wife got the chicken pad see ew. She love pad see ew of all types. I think she just likes thick flat noodles. The ratio of chicken, veggies, and noddles were perfect. I ate her eggs though because she's slightly allergic to eggs. 
Would I come here again?
No. Not because I live in US but because I don't think this place stands out as a Thai restaurant.

Is the wait worth it?? Depends on how discerning is your palate for fine food.  The food tastes very good, but if you have sugar / salt sensitivities you may wish to ask for less sugar / salt in your food.

This was actually a tough one for me! The food was incredible the service was excellent and with the idea of accommodating as many people as possible in the restaurant, I was put into a seat that was fairly tight for a person of my size.... that being said, the atmosphere is really cool but it was tough for me to enjoy the entire experience staring at a stone wall 2 feet from my face. Once again I totally get the need to move customers through and I love the fact that walk in availability is possible otherwise this review would've been at least five..... 100% this is not the last time I will be back to this restaurant! It is absolutely incredibly delicious and if you're on the fence, you absolutely need to go!!! with better seating I'm sure that your experience will absolutely be a five!
Thanks again!!
Zeke

4.5 
Came here for dinner and because we were willing to sit at the communal table, were seated right away. Which was actually great because it was a huge table and we had our own corner that was a lot roomier than most tables.
The winning dish was the mango salad- so fresh and flavorful! The other dishes, pad Thai, pad see ew, and Panang curry were all good-I think we were expecting a little more or different with the Michelin hype.
The ambience of the place is very fun and lively-it's in the basement of a building and feels like a semi tropical hideaway. Service was also good.

i got there at 8:30 on a monday night with a party of two and waited only five minutes! 
the inside is decorated really nicely with thai mementos and souvenirs. 
green curry was really good but some of the beef were too stringy and dry. really strong coconut taste (which i loved)! 
miang kung was really good but too little toppings for too many leaves  wish there were a few more piece of shrimp... 
friend said her pad see ew was one of the best she's ever had. 
thai iced tea is a little too sweet for me

This place is definitely packed 24/7 and super duper loud!
Came here before 5pm and was told there's already a 20 mins wait.  However, got a text message in less than 10 mins so it wasn't too bad.
The seats/tables were small and I had multiple bags with me so it made it extra difficult to sit.  People also kept walking behind me and knocking off my belongings.  I wish I had the a seat against the wall but oh wells...
Ordered few things to try.  The pork skewer was the bomb! The chicken curry was good but the bamboo rice wasn't enough to finish the whole curry dish.  We ended up ordering another rice to go with it.  The tom yum soup was tasty.  The pad thai with beef was chewy.  The beef was super overcooked and it tasted like liver?  The thai tea was super cold and sweet.
Don't think I'll come back to this location, but perhaps the one in midtown.  We were super thirsty after dinner...

Amazing food and great customer service!
We ordered 2 main dish and an appetizer and it was more than enough for 2 people.
I definitely will come back here.

10/10 the one thing you have to order is their combination platter. Me and my friend (another girl with a small appetite) shared it and still had leftovers. Everything was delicious, the meats, the sauces in a way that you can't make in your own kitchen.

This place exceeded my expectations. By far the best, freshest, Thai food I have had in my life. Service was amazing. Drinks were killer. The food had my mouth watering the whole time. I was excited for the next dish to come out. Ambiance is fun and trendy. 
We ordered the pad Thai, the pad see ew noodles, spring rolls and the moo-ping. Everything was full of flavor, piping hot, and mouth watering. Cocktails were amazing as well - my favorite being the Thai mojito. 
They have reservations available for you to make but I love that they cut back their reservation amount to accommodate more walk in guests. They really know what they are doing. Just a lovely experience.

Khao soi tasted better the day after than day of imo. Still very good but I wasn't blown away by it. The Thai milk tea was sooo good, I loved it. Server was super nice and the vibes are cute in there.

Seeking a restaurant with all the vibes?!
++ COME HERE!
Vibes on vibes to be experienced at Pai Northern Thai Kitchen. Lanterns, colorful flag banners, Edison lights, intricate wood paneling, and exposed brick all help set the mood here. 
Craving an adventure, without leaving the city?!
++ COME HERE!
Not only is the vibe authentic AF, but the story behind the concept is just the best. Head to their website to read about their literal journey!
Yearning for authentic bites bursting with flavor?
++ COME HERE!
I was stoked to sample the Tom Yum Soup and Chicken Pad Thai. They were both drool-worthy dishes to say the least. I love an authentic Pad Thai that isn't dripping in sauce. This for the bill. And the Tom Yum Soup left me craving more.
Want to dabble in the kitchen yourself?!
++ COME HERE!
Well, not actually "here," but you can order a copy of their cookbook via their website and cook up some of their killer recipes for yourself. Score!
Pai Northern Thai Kitchen is easily at the top of my "Must Nosh" lost in Toronto. Check it out for yourself!
**Pro Tip: This place is POPPING during dinner on weekends. Do yourself a favor and make a dang reservation or be prepared for a thirty to forty-five minute wait.

This place is an authentic northern Thai restaurant that serves up delicious food all around. In an unassuming basement from outside, they have done a great job in transforming the interiors to make it feel warm and cozy with a touches of Thailand all around. The cocktails were well prepared and presented nicely. We had the Pad Thai, Khao Soi and the Pad Gra Prow as mains. And ended it with a Mango Stickt Rice for dessert. The taste was amazing l, well prepared and presented and large portion sizes. All in  all a great place for good Thai food.

Friday night dinner. Tried to book 2 weeks in advance but there was no table available for reservations. They have limited reservations available to welcome more walk-in guests. So, took a chance and waited in line to get a table. Seated in 30 mins. Already a long line up in front of the restaurant around 5:30pm. This Michelin mentioned restaurant is giving the street and the eat-in area an exciting vibe with full of energy.  
We are group of 5. Ordered
Food: 
# THAI CHICKEN WINGS
# GRABONG (buttercup squash fritters )
# MOO PING (grilled pork skewers)
# GAENG KIAW WAN - GREEN CURRY (Chicken) 
# GAENG MASSAMAN (Beef)
# PAD SEE EW (Shrimp)
Highlight was Pad See Ew. Loved the Wide flat noodle. Great texture with chewiness and tenderness. The wide surface noodle absorbs savory flavors, making a great contrast with the plumpy large shrimps and crispy baby gailan (Chinese broccoli). 
The presentation of the green curry was impressive - the curry was in the coconut shell. Tasted great with generous amount of vegetables and meat, rich in textures and flavors. The accompanying jasmine rice was perfectly steamed, wrapped in a leaf. Flavorful. Compared to the amount of the curry, I wished the size of the rice were bigger. You can order the rice separately for $4. Sweet with mild spice kick. 
The wings, pork skewers, Massaman curry and Grabong all tasted great. Nothing to complain about, but nothing to note as "wow".     
Drinks (Cocktails)
# GOJI ANUNOBY (Vodka, Grande Marnier, Domain de Canton, Plum Wine,Plum Bitters, Goji Pop Tea, Goji Berries.)
# THAI MOJITO (White Rum, Lemongrass Syrup, fresh basil, lime, topped with Soda and butterfly pea flower)
# RED PAI SANGRIA (Malbec, Grand Marnier, lychees, fresh pineapple, pomegranate juice, lime)
All the cocktails had unique Thai flavors with distinctive use of herbs and spices, fruits. Everything hit a good balance of sour, and exotic scent and fruitiness. They all maintained nice boozy kick. 
The amount of food were perfect for 5 adults. Will come back!!!!!

Loved everything about it! I love northern Thai food, and this place delivered. The service is nice and efficient. The space feels fun and trendy, and I love all the decor from Thailand. The food is really really good. I ordered the khao soi with chicken and it was super tasty. It came with noodles and I also ordered rice to sop up the leftover curry. Glad I got to try it and recommend!

So good! Dishes were generous and flavorful. What completed the meal were the drinks that combine Thai flavors into a sweet drink. The skewers are solid, reminds me of food home bbq food in my family! Other two dishes had distinct flavors of spicy, sweet, and savory. The space is large and we were able to get a table without a reservation. Would come back again if I'm in the area!

Hubby and I saw this place on YouTube's "Worth It" and we were curious and had to try this place out. Is it all hype or is it "Worth It?"
I loved the Mango Slaw as I found it refreshing. I loved the textures of the sweetness of the mangos with the crunchiness of the taro sticks and peanuts. It is a must get, in my book. Hubby and I decided to go vegetarian for our entrees. Hubby ordered Tofu Pad Gra Prow which was very good while I ordered Tofu Khao Soi. There was a perfect balance between the curry and soup. The harmonious coconut milk with the stock made it the standout dish with its refreshing combination of flavors and textures. I truly appreciate the notion that they offer plenty of vegetarian food and can make any dish vegan. 
This is a trendy place and you should make reservations on Friday nights as well as the weekends. The service was fast and efficient. They offer dinner specials but the waitress explained everyone at the table would have to order it in order for it to come into effect. The ambiance with live bands on weekends and the overall trendy atmosphere adds an extra layer of enjoyment to the dining experience.  
So the question remains, "Is it Worth It?" The answer is unequivocally, "YES!" It definitely lived up to the hype for us.

My friend and I wanted to catch up over dinner on a Saturday evening, and she picked this place (as she read great reviews). 
We didn't have a reservation, so we waited in line and the friendly staff at the front took down one of our names. Then we were informed that it would be about 30 minute wait and were asked to wait until our name was called. 
While waiting, we looked around- the vibe was energetic and fun, the customers were eating and laughing. The decor was cool- the lights were dimmed, there were various colourful objects all around to evoke a comfy feel. 
I thought the place was pretty small, until our name was called and we were led to a table by a friendly young lady. The place was huge- there were multiple sections and each section had its own decor! Our seat was at the end section, where the decor reminded us of sitting inside someone's home. 
Our server was a second friendly young lady. She warmly greeted us and showed us the menu (QR code). She said she'll be back to take our order in a few minutes. 
To start, we ordered Shrimp Chips and two Thai Ice Tea. For the main, I picked Chef Nuit Pad Thai with chicken. My friend chose Khao Soi with beef. 
A few minutes later, the Shrimp Chips and two Thai Ice Tea came to us. The Shrimp Chips were delicious- they were crispy and lightly salty. The Thai Ice Tea was tasty- it tasted like milk tea with deeper tea flavour. 
Then our mains came and we couldn't wait to eat! For my meal, the blend of veggies, chewy noodles, and the chicken pieces were delicious- however it was a bit salty. My friend enjoyed her meal as well- she said that she liked the smooth coconut curry with blend of spices and the juicy pieces of beef. 
Throughout our meal, our server came by to check-in on us to make sure that we had everything we needed. 
The portions were generous and the dishes and drinks were delicious! Highly recommended!

Don't be put off by the not so glam exterior, it's a stark 360 contrast when you enter through the doors. The sign as you enter says 'Voted as the best Thai restaurant in Toronto', I don't know about Toronto but it's by far the best Thai food I have eaten in North America and I eat a lot of Thai :) My group of 8 came closer to kitchen close but the food was amazing. The Khao sui and Pad Si that I had was so flavorful. I wish I had more time in Toronto, I would have definitely come for a 2nd time. Our server was great, too, and service was pretty quick for a large group. Unfortunately, I couldn't try the mango slaw I had heard so much about. It wasn't available. I'm saving this for next time.

I was let down by Pai. Got seated on a Monday and place was packed. Waited 45 minutes for my food and came cold. After we were given our food then I asked if we could get silverware. The mango sticky rice was amazing. The drunken noodles were good especially if they had been warm. I have a lot of friends who do takeout from here and are fans but I just didn't get the hype.

Stopped by for an early dinner and beat the dinner rush. The service was quick & friendly. The garlic shrimp & ginger beer was a great start to the meal. Both were delicious and the dip for the shrimp was extra tasty. First time trying the Khao Soi with braised beef and was not disappointed. The pickled vegetables and spicy sauce perfected the dish! Ended up taking the mango with sticky rice. Great meal and would highly recommend!!

We went here on a Thursday to get in line around 11:50am. This restaurant doesn't open until 12pm and there was already a line before it opened!
We got the Gaeng Massaman, Chef Built Pad Thai, and Thai Chicken Wings. I also wanted to order dessert too, but they don't serve dessert until after 4pm, so I only ended up getting those food items. Anyways, all the food was good, but it wasn't the best Thai food I've had. The food were very average in flavor. The Thai Chicken Wings were my favorite part though! Those chicken wings were covered were crispy, well marinated, and juicy!
Another positive thing about my experience with the food here was the large portion size of the pad Thai! We shared the pad Thai and that made us full. The Gaeng Massaman curry dish we got was good too and I liked how the curry wasn't too thick.
I'd recommend this place, but maybe only during their dinner hours. I recommend to come during the dinner hours because then you'll be able to try their dessert menu while also being able to order from their food menu too! I also wish this place had more variety of food items since it didn't feel like much variety when I went.

I was in Toronto attending the annual TIFF film festival, and dined at this restaurant on my birthday. I wanted a nice meal and a break from all the movies, and the large crowd hanging around out front and the hour-long wait for a table reassured me that this was going to be a tasty meal. I put my name on the list and waited for a text that my table was ready. (The hostess asked if we would be okay sitting at a communal table, so be aware if you're super private and would prefer to dine alone). 
The restaurant is in a basement, so it's very dark and intimate inside. It is packed with tables, so you'll run a gauntlet to get to your table. The atmosphere is casual and lively, and it's very loud inside with concrete floors and walls. The decor is casual and fun, with colorful flags adorning the walls and a large bar in the center.
Since it was my birthday, we decided to order a bottle of prosecco that was listed on the menu. The friendly server took that order and disappeared, only to return to say they didn't have any bottles of prosecco, and we'd have to order by the glass. Big disappointment. 
We placed our order for Thai vegetables as an appetizer and we each got their house specialty: Pad Thai. I chose shrimp, my husband chose beef. Our server typed our orders into his electronic pad and disappeared for the remainder of our meal. 
The place was packed and they obviously didn't have enough servers waiting tables, so the service knocks this place down at least one, but probably two, stars. Another thing that really bugged me is that we were charged prices that were higher than what was stated on the menu. I am not sure if this was just the "tourist surprise special" or if they have dynamic pricing during special events downtown, but it rubbed me the wrong way. My prosecco per-glass price was almost three dollars more than listed on the menu, as were our entrees. Not cool.  
I also was annoyed by the volume of noise in the place. It was SO LOUD with people screaming to have conversations. This would've been a killer place for a romantic evening if they could do something about the noise levels. 
The food was really good and made with high quality ingredients, so I can't complain about that at all! In fact, I'll definitely return next time I'm in town for the festival. Note: they won't take reservations during TIFF, so don't bother. But do show up at least an hour before you want to eat, it really did take the quoted time for a table to be ready.

Pai is one of the most popular go-to places lots of locals recommend a lot. Coming into this I had some expectations that it'll live up to the hype. Unfortunately, I found the place a bit overhyped and not mindblowing. 
Pad Thai: Quite average pad thai. It wasn't bad but wasn't really the best pad thai I've had especially since it's a reasonably high price point.
Papaya Salad & Mango Salad: The papaya salad came with shrimp chips and vermicelli. The mango salad had low quantity of mango, was mostly carrots. Was a bit too much MSG on the salad seasoning. 
Khao Soi: The better dish out of all of them. The broth was flavourful and creamy. Everything went well together. Would recommend only getting this and perhaps their curry dishes as it seems like that's their specialty. 
Overall, I had much better expectations for this spot and disappointed that Pai doesn't live up to the hype they receive. Although I will give them credit they have an extensive menu which may be good for groups that have a lot of dietary restrictions. It's not worth the long wait (over 40 mins wait time) or far in advanced reservations in my opinion.

Great thai foods. Beware of a wait for table if you come during dinner hours. We can see why this is one of the most popular restaurants in Toronto. The foods were authentically cooked and the service was very good. The mango salads and fried chicken wings were delicious. Laab at Pai based on Northern Thai recipe was delicious, beware that this is different than regular sour Laab that you would usually have at most Thai restaurants. Mango with sticky rice was the best! Great place to eat with friends and family.

Food quality is always consistent but portion has definitely gone down. Either as a result of shrinkflation or rising cost of ingredients. There was barely lettuce in my salad and my salad had more meat pieces than lettuce. Was very disappointed.

Great evening for Pai!
We walked in on a stormy night to a full house. But we were seated shortly after and directed to access their wifi and menu online.
We ordered several items...
Mango slaw... favorite dish
Pad see ew noodles with tofu and veggies 
Fried rice with shrimp 
Vegan seafood dish
Pangang curry with tofu and veggies 
Green tea... pretty light in taste but hot which was appreciated on a cold, windy night.
The dishes were generously plated, smokey, and hit the spot. 
The restaurant itself is like walking into a cabana. The music is thumping, the servers are schlepping items back and forth, the tables and bar are buzzing with conversation. It was a fun way to close out our visit to the city.

This seemed to be the most frequently and highly reviewed restaurant in all of Toronto, on both Yelp
And Google, so I had to give it a try. 
When you think of a place like Toronto, your first instinct is that Canadian food would be the most popular. But Canada is a melting pot of cultures, and there's a strong Asian influence here. 
We figured all the rave reviews about this place was reason enough to see what all the hype was about. 
We got here on a Tuesday evening and it was so packed that we waited for 35 minutes!! I couldn't believe how busy it was on a Tuesday. That was my initial indication that I was about to have some good food. 
The ambiance was casual but cool at the same time. Have you ever been to one of those famous people that post famous people's pictures who have visited their restaurant on the wall before? It was very much like that. 
While we were waiting for a table we decided to have a drink at the bar. There were no bar stools which was great because we didn't have to fight anyone for the bartenders attention, so we stayed standing up ordering drinks and enjoying them. We had the Lowry and the Thai mojito, my fiancés favorite was the Lowry and mine was the Thai mojito. Both were Very smooth and easy to drink. 
Once we sat down, the service was incredibly fast which was surprising since it was so busy. We were attended to right away, they would come back
To check on us and if we needed anything, it wouldn't take long to get it. 
We noticed that the most popular item on Yelp was the pad Thai, so even though it's such a typical Thai food item, we had to try it. The pad Thai was really good, we got almost the spiciest level (faraang spicy) and added extra spice on the side but it wasn't as spicy as Thai food in LA where we're originally from usually is. The pad Thai was my fiancés favorite all time pad Thai, I'm a little bit more of a food snob, to me it was a solid 4.5 star out of 5, loved it but I feel like I've had slightly better, but it was definitely top 10 I've ever had everywhere I've traveled. 
We ordered the grabong (squash fritters), even though we read a review from someone saying that it didn't have flavor. Let me tell you, as long as you dip it in the dip they provide you, it is popping full of flavor. By itself without the dip, it's pretty plain. We loved it and dipped to our hearts content. 
I noticed the Khao Soi soup looking dish seemed like my kind of meal, so I couldn't pass up ordering it, and I'm glad I did. There was so much broth that after eating it with the noodles, I ordered white rice and added it into the soup and it's like I had 2 meals from the same dish. And in my opinion it was great with noodles but even better with the white rice!! The flavor was also finger licking good. 
I would love to come back and try more dishes here

PAI's OG Location is a spacious basement level facility. Reservations are recommended for large groups as walk-ins for 2-4 can be 30-45 mins wait on less busy days. (i.e. Tuesday 18:00-19:00)
The service was great, they will do their best to note and make accommodations for allergens. Came over frequently to check and the food came quickly after ordering.
PAI's Thai Iced Tea is the most balanced Thai iced tea I've tried so far in TO. It isn't tooo fluorescently orange, nor overly sweet, it has great balance, smoothness, and taste. My go-to for Thai restaurants are the Pad Thai, Thai Iced Tea, Khao Soi, and/or a Green Curry. Everything was great! The Grabong was crispy and a great app and I will be back to try a curry and/or a rice dish in the future.
Order
- Khao Soi Chicken
- Grabong
- Pad Thai Chicken
- Thai Iced Tea

This is a dimly lit, noisy, and popping place, so be forewarn. I did appreciate that they had a small waiting area and all staff was working efficiently to get guests in and out. The menu is typical of your usual Thai restaurant. The Khao Soi was bit too thick and sweet in my opinion. The egg noodles was surprisingly better than i had anticipated in this dish though. The Thai chicken wings were mediocre at best. Nevertheless, the dip definitely brought this dish up a notch. We should have done without the Pad Gra Prow - crispy pork. Other than the pieces of crispy pork, everything was very mediocre about this dish. This was our first time here and will probably be our last.

Hands down the best Thai food we've ever experienced, including a month in Thailand. 
Thai Villa in NYC was our favorite until we found this gem. Recommended by so many sites, my expectations were high and I was cautiously optimistic. Arriving at 6:30pm, they were already on a 45-minute wait. 
From start to finish everything was incredible and the service was stellar. 
Thai Iced Tea
Shrimp Appetizer
Pad See Ew
Panang Curry
Run so not walk!

We read and heard that this Is a good thai restaurant and reservation was highly recommended. 
We called and got a message to reserve online. We went online and it looked like there weren't any tables available. We decided to check it out regardless. 
We arrived at 3 pm. Plenty of open tables. We reviewed the menu and realized all the salads were only available after 4 pm. Odd and a major bummer.
For that reason, we ordered the pad phet chicken with extra spicy heat level. It came out mild with side of red chili oil. We asked raw thai chili to give it a kick. The food was expensive and didn't have the wow factor.

Had the Thai Chicken Wings, Pad Thai, Khao Soi, and "The Lowry".
Overall really great atmosphere, amazing food and customer service from the waiters that served us at the bar. Definitely recommend!

Pai has hands down the best pad thai i've had. I can't think of a better pad thai place in both Toronto and the states, even those in LA or NYC. The tom yum is also so flavorful and delicious. The wait can be a while if you didn't reserve a spot. Highly recommend stopping by for some thai food if you're in the city!

Excellent, friendly, and attentive service; cute decor and lively atmosphere; and delicious food. We got the wings, spring rolls (so good we ordered more!), green curry, and a chicken vegetable stir fry dish. Everything was really flavorful, arrived quickly and was served piping hot. Would definitely return the next time I'm in town.

What a great way to kick off our first meal in Toronto! Since it was the highest reviewed spot we figured it has to be good! We went for a late lunch, around 3:30-4ish. They told us it would be about a 20 minute wait but we only waited like 10 minutes.
For food we ordered the Pai Thai with chicken and the Khao Soi Beef 22 CAD each. Omg you NEED to order the Khao Soi, I could literally just drink the sauce forever. The Pai Thai was good but I feel like I've had better, it wasn't bad just not the best I've ever had. 
Portions are pretty substantial, so you could probably share and get an appetizer.
The decor inside is cool, with fun details. Service was good and staff was friendly. I definitely recommend visiting this place while in Toronto!!

My husband and I were craving authentic Thai food. We searched on Yelp and this was the winner. We had the pad Thai and fried rice. Both of the dishes were delicious with generous portions. We were able to customize the spice level with each dish too. We also ordered the Thai tea. It was creamy, sweet, and refreshing! It paired perfectly with the spicy food  
Overall, the service was great and the staff were friendly.

Arrived on a Friday night right before going to a musical next door. It was about 6:10pm and there was already a line outside, which signalled to me I should have high expectations as a first timer here. For a table for 2, it ended up being a 25 minute wait. 
Surprisingly, the restaurant inside is a lot bigger than what you see when you first step in. I thought the restaurant only seated all the people I could see in that area which looked to be about 60 people. But when it came to my turn to head to my table, I had to maneuver through at least 2 mini rooms to get to there! Upon my partner's high recommendation, I ordered the Khao Soi Beef for $23. This dish was phenomenal. The soup had right amount of sweet and spicyness, the tender beef melted in my mouth once I took a bite, and the noodles paired perfectly with the flavours. 
One thing I will say is that portion wise, I didn't leave feeling full and had to grab a dinner after the musical because I was hungry again, but I felt like the quality of the dish still deserves 5/5.
I ordered the pad pak reum with chicken and it was so good! It was packed with flavour, lots of vegetables and lots of chicken. This is my favourite Thai restaurant in Toronto hands down!

Service was amazing despite an overwhelming amount of customers, we ordered a bunch of dishes to share and for the most part everything was excellent.  The ambiance is a bit loud but warranted given the amount of customers and pub style layout. We tried a number of curry dishes and they were absolutely delicious!  The wings, garlic shrimp and chicken were off the meter. My personal favorite were the northern Thai sausages, the chef pad Thai and the curry oxtails. If in Toronto this place is a definitely must try!

Great Thai option that I would recommend if you're in the CN Tower area.
Pad gra prow- I ordered the ground chicken and this dish was very flavorful. I frequently order this at other Thai restaurants but none of them have the depth of flavor and coherence between the rice and the flavored ground chicken.
Chiang Mai beef noodle soup- this dish had many components that all sang in harmony. The braised beef was nice and lean without any fatty tendon that normally comes with it.

10/10 - We had the Cool Mule and my husband said it's the best mule he's ever had. The Ninja Sake beverage was amazing too. For dinner we had Pad Thai and the Khao Soi - SPEECHLESS. 10/10. We might come back tomorrow. The Shrimp Chips were amazing too.

You can't tell from the outside but this place is MASSIVE 
.. there was a long long but for good reason. The line goes fast and have a coconut water and Thai ice tea was great. Some of the best Thai food of my life. We live in Pittsburgh PA, and Toronto is a five hour drive cool city and this place will make it work the drive.

Our party of 7 came for late lunch on a Wednesday afternoon and had no wait. Thankfully we made a reservation as it was still very busy despite it being 2pm.
We ordered the chicken wings (crispy skin), pad see ew (too sweet), khao soi, gaeng massaman, pad gra prow, khao pla twat. For drinks, we got the goji anunoby (light plum wine taste), Thai mojito (pretty), tea mac (no taste of alcohol), and cool mule. Our favorite dishes were the khao soi, curry, and fried fish, all which were seasoned well and had the right amount of spice. 
We love that they could accomodate a peanut allergy among our group and were patient when we didn't know what to order. Unfortunately 60% of the menu can't be ordered until after 4pm which sucked because more of the interesting dishes were among that time.
Definitely recommend this place with a reservation after 4pm!

Came on a Sunday around 5pm and were seated immediately. Visiting from California so we ordered a ton of dishes to try, such as the mango slaw, moo ping, pad thai, khao soi, and the pad gra pow. Everything was excellent!! So flavorful and nothing was overcooked :) We also got several drinks because they were so well priced (but that could be because everything is just ridiculously priced in Cali). Overall, the vibe in here was so fun and lively and will definitely recommend this spot to anyone, even locals!

Some of the most amazing Thai food I've ever had! Never thought I would find this kind of food in Toronto. Definitely come when it opens because it fills up very quickly. Staff members were very nice. Rustic looking with some traditional Thai elements throughout the restaurant. 
The pad Thai was SOOO good. I have to put it up as one of my top three pad Thai I have ever had. I ordered mine with shrimp. My husband thoroughly enjoyed his khao soi and he said it was also one of the best khao soi he's ever had. Honestly a bit expensive for Thai food but I think it was totally worth trying. Such good food! 
Would highly recommend!

Absolutely loved this place! There was a wait time for 25 minutes, but I was called within 5 minutes of joining the wait list. The waiter took the time to go over the entire menu and explained which ones I could go with according to my taste pallete. 
Got to try their lychee cocktail which is Tequila based and also ordered their Pad grow Pro vegan bacon which was out of the world. It's a must try!!  Ambience was good too with enough seating and waiting area

My girlfriend and I needed some Thai food in our life while we're visiting Toronto and Pai looked exactly what we were looking for. The place has really cute decor and the staff is extremely nice. They have a pretty extensive menu so there's a little bit of something for everyone. My gf and I started with the chicken wings and orders Pad Thai and Khao Soi. Both were incredible, the flavors were on point for all three items. We grabbed a few drinks and those were fantatsic as well! Prices were pretty good all around and won't break the bank. 
If my gf and I ever find ourselfs in Toronto we will definitely be back!

Avoid it.
Unfortunately I didn't enjoy much the food. The wait time is too long and the service is bad too. The platter is a disaster, I simply won't recommend it. It's expensive and only look good for picture.

This place is soooo hyped up and well known that I was genuinely shocked by how mediocre the food was! We ordered the Grabong appetizer and the vegan panang curry with tofu and veggies. The appetizer was good, but the panang curry was truly the most bland Thai curry I have ever tasted. They also just threw strips of raw tofu in it. 
Oddly enough, the plain rice was more flavorful BEFORE adding the curry on top. If we hadn't been in a hurry we would have sent the dish back. 
Service wasn't great either--lots of snooty vibes.

Lined up 15 minutes before the doors opened for lunch on a Saturday. More than 30 people lined up behind us. This might be the hottest restaurant in Toronto. Many menu items are only available after 4pm and a group of 4 that knows how to eat can cover most of the lunch menu. There is no question, though, that this is a top tier Thai restaurant. Beautiful preparations, bold flavors, the perfect level up for anyone who is looking to emphatically move beyond takeout pad thai.

Everything was fine up until the food arrived. 
They brought our meal to the wrong table that seated quite a bit after us, after their confusion and poking at the meal they picked the food back up and brought it to our table. 
The Grabong was cold, and cold fried food is just not great. The Pad Cha Hett was ok. My wife's meal was a bit salty. 
In the middle of eating a guy came up and tried to take a plate which we were still eating, I had to get more assertive than you really should need to asking them to leave the $25 appetiser so we could finish it. 
Overall, the food is fine. It's not great.
The service is just absurdly dreadful. There is no reason to get cold dishes, and be served food at a Michelin rated restaurant which has been passed between tables and poked at by other people.
The first impression of the service alone I would never go back.

I've had Pai bookmarked in the event I visit Toronto and this time, I finally got to try it. I was excited because I love Thai food, and it seemed authentic but unfortunately, it fell short. I've read there's always a wait and they don't accept reservations so we decided to go at around 1 PM on a rainy Sunday. We were quoted 45 min wait but only ended up waiting about 25. We ordered a drink at the bar while we waited. I had the Thai mojito and hubby had the Lowry. Both tasted pretty similar even though one was rum and one was gin. It's probably because it was sickeningly sweet, so the sugar was all we tasted. 
For food, a lot of items weren't available until dinner time, so if there's something specific you want to try, keep that in mind. We started with fried garlic shrimp, which was probably the only thing we liked. It was perfectly fried/crispy, and the tamarind dipping sauce it came with was nice. For drinks, hubby got a Thai iced tea which also way too sweet. For my main, I went with the Khao Soi with beef. The beef was flavorless - I had to dunk it in the chili oil it was served with. The broth was too salty. I don't think I was even able to eat half the bowl. I wish it came with more pickled mustard greens. Hubby had the Gaeng Hunglay (sweet and sour garlic-ginger curry with braised oxtail). The flavor wasn't bad but overall still a bit too salty. It could have used way more rice.
Maybe the dinner experience is different/better? But it's not worth the wait/trek/money for a lunch.

Tom yum soup was best I've ever had. Very flavorful! Chicken wings and pad see ew were disappointing. The chicken in the pad see ew was very noticeably old and dry. Had high hopes for this place. Made it before open so waited about 15 mins on a Thursday morning. Restaurant was larger than I expected so that was nice.

Amazing food as always! There can be long wait times so go early and put your name on the waitlist. 
The dishes were all very flavourful but I did wish that the Gaeng Hunglay had slightly more meat. I got the mild spicy which wasn't very spicy at all so if you want more of a kick, I'd recommend medium spicy! 
The ambiance of the place has more of a hole-in-the wall feel, with colourful decor in a lively setting.

One of the best Thai restaurants I've been to hands down. The restaurant is busy and lively with a bit of a wait, especially at peak hour. However, my boyfriend and I got seated within 20 minutes of putting our name down - thanks to the 90 min table limit!
We waited at the bar as we waited for our table. I got the goji anunoboy which was so delicious - very light and refreshing especially being out walking around the hot summer day. My boyfriend got the Mango Sticky Rice IPA which was perfect for him.
Once seated, our server was very attentive and great! We ordered the papaya salad which was SPICY! It was delicious but definitely with a kick. You can ask for your own spice level, but we went all in. Very delicious and super flavorful- highly recommend. 
For our entrees we ordered the pad gra prow and the khai soi. The pad gra prow was phenomenal, literally the best I've ever had. We ordered this with crispy pork and at a farang spice level. It wasn't as spicy as the papaya salad but this is definitely not a dish to pass up. Literally dreaming of this and want to go back to get it as I write this review!
The khao soi was delicious as well and coconut-y if you like that! It comes with red chili oil on the side to adjust your spice level. The broth was fantastic and super creamy and sweet. Highly recommend as this was a staple and everyone around was ordering it!
Definitely recommend!

Excellent food.
The Panang Curry, Pad Thai and Mango Slaw were highlights. 
Loved vibe. They do good trade because they do good food.

Very authentic northern Thai cuisine. The main attraction for this place and probably worth the 45-minute wait is the food. However, the service at this downtown location is sub-par. First, the cocktail I ordered was "lost" (server's exact words) which was why it took another half an hour to get my drink. Then, another server dropped a whole tray of food and drinks, very close to our table. I understand that accidents happen but none of the servers even bothered to check if I was hit by the broken glass or bothered to offer me a napkin or paper towel when the drinks spilled over. Considering this restaurant was credited with a Michelin-mention (not rating), I wish the owners and managers would strive to offer better service to match their food.

The Khan Soi was so good! Very flavorful! Perfect to go with shrimp. The server was so nice and accommodating! I asked if I can get any sort of veggies, he helped to serve a side veggie even it was not on the menu. Very impressed by this restaurant overall experience!

The place was a bit out of the way, in an alley way, and it's in a basement.  We had a little bit of a confusion finding the place, but oh boy, it was sure worth it. And now I think the location is part of their charm.
The food was excellent.  We have been to many  thai places , and this  place is a cut above the rest. 
The commonly known Pad thai, this place managed to put a twist to it and made it a bit different. It was so good. The green curry was delicious!  And they served it in a coconut. The pork skewer was also good, but it was a bit too sweet for my taste. The rice they gave with the green curry was wrapped in banana leaf and tasted like pandan.
The service was excellent.  The vibe was hip.  We will be back when we are in town again.

Hands down the only place you should be eating if you're near Union. For the price, you get so much delicious food and the indoor decor is uplifting. Everyone I know in Toronto raves about Pai and for good reason. They have curries, noodles, rice dishes, etc. you can pick your spice level to customize each dish. Come here and make a reservation because I've heard the lines can be crazy!

Pai was absolutely packed on a Tuesday at 6PM. I made a reservation a month ahead of time and was promptly seated. 
I ordered the Khao soi (4/5 with beef, and the presentation was quite something. The broth was rich and creamy, with strong tastes of coconut. The beef was fine, and the egg noodles were thick and meaty in a good way. My girlfriend got the pad Thai (2.4/5). It was a pretty average pad Thai, nothing special about it. 
The service was below average, and we were seated in a corner and kinda forgotten about for large periods of time.
Overall better than average Thai food, but not quite hitting the right notes for me to earn a 5 star experience. Slightly overhyped.

The place was decorated really well with a tropical theme. It was about an hour wait for our party of 6 on a rainy Wednesday evening in November. The waiting area is very small, most of my family had to stand. I ordered the chaing Mai beef noodle soup, they give you a good amount of meat, and it was very flavorful. I tried my boyfriend's Khao soi (chicken and noodles in coconut milk curry) and it was so creamy, it the best thing I had eaten all month. I recommend dining here, and definitely make a reservation ahead of time.

I loved all of their appetizers and drinks.
However, I was a bit disappointed with their pad thai and pad see ew because they were overly seasoned and extremely salty. 
Servers were very attentive and kind. 
Hesitant to give it another try.
Really enjoyed the experience I had at Pai! I got the chicken fried rice, which was very good. There was a wait, but it was definitely wait. Would definitely come back here again!
The restaurant is popular with local Canadians and it didn't disappoint. My favorite was the curry oxtails and Pad Thai but I feel it's too busy to preserve highest quality of dishes.

Visiting Toronto and our wonderful hotel attendant suggested Pai if we liked Thai food. Happily we do, so off we went on a lovely walk a few blocks to Pai. 
The place was happening and nearly packed. There were many people ahead of us waiting and we decided to wait as well, knowing it was close to 45 minutes before we should be seated. This is where 1 star is removed. There was no bar service in the waiting area nor could you order an appetizer while you waited. 
It looked like they had ample staff to bring drinks while you waited but it is what it is. 
At exactly 45 minutes we were called and brought to our table. The menu is excellent with many wonderful choices. We went simple as the waitress suggested the classic Pad Thai. We had vegetable Pad Thai and chicken Pad Thai. Both were fantastic with a flavor different from what we know at home but also wonderful. It was worth the wait. 
Back to the scene. Great old classic rock and pop music was piped in and the energy of the diners and staff was "On." At 17:00 on the tick, doors opened to expand to a larger space with a full-on bar and cool clerestory windows if you will. This place is actually half a floor down from street level. The daylight brought another level of energy and excitement to the place. I think this would make a massively cool place to hang out with a group of friends, enjoy great food, and a few drinks. 
I'll be back next time in Toronto!

Made a reservation for 8 on a Tuesday night at 6pm a month in advance because their reservations open up a month before your desired date. They gave us the private room in the back which was really nice because we had our own privacy and they had  a lot of Thai artwork in the room. Although it was a Tuesday night, the restaurant was packed to the fullest and there were a lot of people going in and out. Highly recommend a reservation!
The service was great! We at least had like 3-4 employees check on us throughout. They were all really friendly and welcoming.
The food was really yummy and lived up to the hype, but was it the best Thai food I've ever had? Not so much. Some dishes like the garlic chicken and garlic shrimp didn't really have flavor. It was just breaded and deep fried. The standouts were the green curry and the papaya salad. 
I'm glad I tried this place!

I researched the "Best Thai in Toronto" and on every site I saw Pai was at the top. Needless to say I had to try it, and I am thankful that I did and that I ordered in advance. The line outside was waiting with anticipation and I now know why.
My first experience was disappointing because the garlic chicken was not available. However the garlic shrimp was! And thank you food Gods. It was delicious! I also ordered the Pad Thai I held off on the spice BIG MISTAKE because I would've never done this nor have I until this visit.
Despite not having the spice the Pad Thai with chicken was packed with flavor.
As for the Ambiance j my brief visit, this place is a vibe and a half. I don't live in Toronto but when I'm back I will surely visit!
