Plah Nua - beef salad. GET IT CUZ IT'S SO SO GOOD. I don't even like mint leaves and I gobbled this up. Beef cooked to perfect level for this dish and lots of it, more than I expected. 
Khao Soi - egg noodles in coconut curry with chicken drumsticks. Order an extra bowl of rice so that delicious delicious curry doesn't go to waste. Or take it home and enjoy the next day. 
Thai iced tea - nice size, a little bit sweeter than I like it but I let the ice melt a bit and it was fine after that. 
Prices are very decent in comparison to other Thai restaurants. The ratio of actual food to sauce is higher than normal which is a big win for me since I hate going to places that use filler vegetables (green peppers) and little meat in their dishes. You can tell that a lot of thought and care went into preparing the planning of their menu. 
I'm definitely looking forward to my next visit to try other items!
Very nice clean Thi food ... i liked the rice with chicken and fried eggs on the top ... the Fried shrimp was very nice too. Sorry didnt take pic for the food .. was so hungry this time.
Everything here tastes amazing and the staff is really friendly. Pai is my new favourite restaurant on MealPal. I've yet to try a dish I don't love.

Very good experience. The food is authentic Thai tasting with a slight twist of the chef's innovation for extra flavors. The morning glory vegetable is one of the highlights of this place. It's a traditional Thai vegetable cooked in amazing sauce. Only real Thai restaurants serve this dish.

Love this restaurant! Amazing delicious food and excellent service everytime! The only thing is it gets very crowded (prepandemic), and the music gets very loud. I felt so claustrophobic that I had to go outside for some air. Maybe it'll be different now, I haven't gone back yet since reopening of restaurant. 
But it's still one of my favourite restaurants in Toronto!

This place is POPPIN. I wouldn't say for a certain reason, per say, but we waited 2 hours for a table... The location is nice and the aesthetic of the place is satisfying. I enjoyed the food a lot but some of my friends didn't enjoy it too too much (some can be picky). The night that we went it was obvi very busy so our waiter wasn't very attentive but I was in an understanding mood at the time. Overall food was a 4, location and environment were a 5, and experience was a 3.

Came here to check out the hype from social media.
The restaurant was surprisingly not jam-packed and we came around thirty minutes after 12 on a Saturday.  We were seated at the stools instead of the traditional seating at the back as that table could only seat up to 4 people (we had 6 people). 
I ordered the Pad Grow with crispy pork, as its one of their featured dish. Tasted similar to the Taiwanese minced pork rice. The difference is the egg is not boiled but pan fried. Since I got the mild version, the flavour was okay. It wasn't bland but it lacked a bit of flavour too. Will try the spicier version next time.

Hands down my favourite Thai place!!! Be prepared to line up if you don't come early for dinner! This place can be packed!! Service is decent and at a good pace for a place this busy. It can be a bit on the noisier side so if you are bringing a date and one of you is quiet, it might be a little harder to hear. 
I really enjoy their beef brisket khao soi and their pad Thai is really good too! Friends have also enjoyed their papaya salad and their chicken wings.

Although the establishments atmosphere was exactly as reflected within the reviews, I must say that the positive correlation did not extend to the food.  From a presentation perspective, the staff was extremely courteous and attentive to our needs.  The food was plated with care; nonetheless, the flavor profile left much to the imagination.  We found the food bland, which is contradictory to the cuisine.  We ordered the PAD THAI (Chicken) and PAD GRA PROW (Pork) as our main dish with Thai Chicken wings and GRABONG as our appetizers (which were not bad).  We are from the US so our palate may be more accustomed to robust flavors; notwithstanding, the Tea Mac and Summer Dog cocktails were superb.

Everything was amazing. It's a busy place from the time they open at noon. Friday around 1220pm there was a 40 minute wait and it was worth every minute. For appetizers we had the wings and fried shrimp. They were both so damn good we ordered a second round. It was 6 of us with 6 different entrees and each was excellent. I should have written this review right away because I can't remember the dishes. Service and timing for food arrival was on point. I would definitely eat here again and wait in line if it was busy.

This is my favourite thai restaurant in Toronto, and many people share the same sentiments... which is why you should be prepared to wait a while before you can indulge in the food! Service & atmosphere is always good. I usually order their green curry with chicken which is served in a coconut. It comes with rice on the side as well as a small bowl of extra curry that didn't make it into the coconut. The curry is so flavourful! I really like the bamboo shoots, green peppers, and basil inside too. Paired with their thai iced tea, you can't go wrong. I've heard great things about their khao soi as well - I've been meaning to try that but I always end up with the green curry that never fails me.

Whenever I crave Thai food, I think about Pai! They're always busy, but I never had a problem getting a seat since I was always dining with one other person. It can become quite noisy, but if you can get past that you will love it!
Dishes we ordered on my last visit for dinner: 
Gai Satay ($12.50) - The chicken was very juicy and tender, and the peanut sauce added a delicious mix of nutty, sweet and tangy flavours.
Laap Salad ($15) - This was my first time trying a Laap Salad and I was intrigued by all the different ingredients that went into making this dish. I really enjoyed the salad because the pork mix had a delicious complexity of flavours with a strong kick from the chilies. The slices of cucumber added a refreshing touch to help balance out the spice.
Starter Tom Yum Soup with Shrimp ($6.50) - If you're a fan of sour foods like me, you will love this tom yum soup! The soup was very rich, spicy and sour, a great pick-me-up for someone who's feeling under the weather.
Pad Gra Prow with Beef ($15) - The pad gra prow with beef was one of the new dishes I fell in love with. The stir fried ground beef was extremely flavourful and mouthwatering. If you'd like to try a new dish, but not keen on being too adventurous, I highly recommend this dish.
Khao Soi with Shrimp ($17) - Another fantastic new dish that I tried. The golden curry was delicious and had a thick and creamy consistency, and the egg noodles were very soft and fresh. 
I have to say that Pai is one of my favourite restaurants in Toronto and if I lived downtown I would probably eat there once a week. Check them out if you haven't already, you will fall in love with their food!

Covid is a very stressful economic environment for restaurants to be operating in, in that they are hoping that they will survive the storm. On the other hand if you are  going to support a business shouldn't they be operating with respect to their patrons?  I ordered and picked up Khao Soi tonight.  I went home to be disappointed in the 3 cups of coconut milk sauce I received and 1 once of chicken breast, and believe me I weighted the chicken!  This is a terrible disregard for customers.  You can fool some of the people some of the time, but they will never fool me again, and perhaps never fool anyone who reads this post.
Khao Soi and their Grambong fries are my go-to orders always! They never dissappoint. Their Pad Thai recipe unfortunately is too sweet for me.

Cool and casual bohemian ambience with fantastic food! I had beef masaman curry which was full of thick, coconut flavour and the meat was so tender. The petite potatoes in the curry were an absolute delight. I also tried Khao Soi from my friends and it was also delicious. It has flat noodles and the gravy works as a soup-ish base. Comes with braised beef/chicken breasts/drumsticks. All of those meat options work great with the flavour. It's super filling though so come hungry. I also tried the the basil and crispy pork with egg on top--if you like spicy, definitely take this dish!! Even tho we went for lunch, this has a more dinner-y vibe with a cocktail menu and all. Loved the place overall and definitely coming back !

One of my favourite restaurants in Toronto and definitely worth the wait. Go early, leave your name and number down for a table, then go to one of the nearby bars for a drink while you wait. 
Pad Thai - one of the best and most flavourful Pad Thais in the city. Comes with chopped peanuts on the side, and you can select your spiciness level. 
Khao Soi - a heavier noodle soup. Soup is incredibly flavourful and creamy
Chang Mai Beef Noodle Soup - slight hint of heat, and incredibly flavourful soup base. Beef is tender and melts in your mouth. Wonton chips on top add the perfect bit of crunch. 
Only issue is we had to wait about 30 minutes for our food to arrive after we ordered.

Around: $20/person
Summary: A slight more expensive thai food place, with good service, but OK food.
Wait time: long~
Tips: do not ordered curry as take out during dinner
I know this place is probably a popular joint for thai food. However, I just found it a OK. I like Khan San Road better (moved to a new place now). This place does not give me a "Wow" feeling like Khan San Road.
I have been here a couple of times.
I ordered curry to go. For around $40, I got 2 very small box of curry. I knew for sitting down, the curry came in a coconut, however, for to go, it is just in a plastic bowl. Tastes good, but the portion is tiny.
I also been sat down for lunch, ordered curry again. I was expecting a curry in a coconut like dinner time, however, it just came in a metal bowl. I guess they cut down the cost during lunch, and the curry tastes a bit too salty. The thai ice tea is also too too too sweet to drink. I just ended up dilute with water.
Maybe I ordered wrong curry dish, but it takes like average curry I could get at Thai restaurant and a bit expensive as well.

Went here for a work offsite - Food was out faster than I could order a drink.  I want to say that that was a bad thing, but  it wasn't.  
Being at a work function, it was probably better that I did not pump system full of liquor.. as much as I would've liked that.
End of the day - outstanding!
Amazing food! Great vibes! I would recommend going on a weekday when they first open. The wait is pretty long if you go later. You can also reserve on their website but spots fill up pretty fast.

Amazing Thai Food!
This is as real as it gets in the city! Note: if you do not have a spice tolerance, make sure you choose conservatively when you choose your spice level.
The green curry is delicious, creamy and full of veggies and meat. When it comes in the young coconut, it is beautiful, and the young coconut adds a beautiful spice break and richness to the dish.
The red curry with beef is SUPER flavourful and delicious, there are both fried noodles and boiled noodles in this dish which are a beautiful textural component. The dish is incredibly filling.
The pad thai was delicious and very flavourful and served fresh and hot (noodles were chewy and not overdone at all). The chicken wings were delicious with their sauce and the different spices and herbs made is super yummy with strong thai flavours. 
The mojito type drink (cannot remember the name, but it had mint, gin and citrus) was very good, but a little on the sweeter side. The seasonal coconut ice cream was to die for (I was already bursting but somehow managed to pack it in on account of how delicious it was). 
Service was good and the ambience is cute (though not necessarily thai). There are cure sitting areas at the front, but the place fills up fast!

This is arguably my favourite restaurant in Toronto. Partly because of sentimental reasons and partly because of the amazing deliciousness. Everything is well seasoned and flavourful. Our go-tos are the Khao Soi chicken and Chiang Mai Beef noodles. He loves the Thai Iced tea...it come overly sweet but as you drink, keep adding water to dilute it (if you so choose). The lineups are indicative of their food, so definitely expect to wait in line unless you get there just as the doors open or at odd times. Pai is always my favourite reco for visitors to Toronto!

Restaurant gets busy, but surprisingly the place is pretty big. Arrived 35 minutes before closing on a Monday night and got seated within 15 minutes. Ambience was really cool and unique. 
We ordered two cocktails, the spicy P and Kawhian Punch which both could have used a little more alcohol.  As far as food, we ordered the Pad Thai and the Pad Gra Prow. Overall we thought the food was enjoyable. 
Nice experience

My visit to Pai this time was just OK. I went on a Wednesday evening. 
The food as uaual is outstanding - I am addicted to the Garlic Shrimp and the Khao Soi (I literally order it every time, I'm not joking)
The drinks were also good and quite strong so no complaints.
My only issue this time was the service, or lack there of. We waited about 20 minutes for our table which wasn't terrible, however once seated we waited and waited for someone to come over. I had to flag down the wait staff multiple times throughout the evening to order or ask for things. We ordered drinks and waited for almost 25 minutes before they came - I had to actually ask again for them to which they showed up within 2 minutes...weird. I asked 4 times for a straw. Noone came to check on us once we got our food or ask if we wanted more drinks. We even had to ask for boxes for our left over food.
I will come back because I love this place but the service was so disappointing.
great thai food. affordable rate. delecious. Thanks for the great hospitality

Delicious food, $5 daily shots (flower power is so good), lots of seating, little bit loud but definitely great atmosphere for groups! Line wait was around 15-30 mins for a group of 10, however worth the wait. If you're coming in groups, tips are already included in the total.
I love the golden curry I had here.  It's high end Thai food.  The atmosphere was intimate and I would definitely go again.

This was our favorite dining experience while visiting Toronto. 
We tried the Khao Soi Chicken and the Gaeng Masaman Beef. My favorite was the beef. The sauce was super flavorful, and the beef was very tender. The peanuts mostly sank to the bottom, but provided a nice crunchy surprise.
There was a growing line when we arrived, but we were seated quickly. I was incredibly surprised to realize how large this restaurant is. There is seating for about 250 people throughout the sprawling basement space. The waitstaff and kitchen were efficient, and we received our order in about 10-15 minutes. The line had grown even longer by the time we left - always a good sign you've found a great place to enjoy!

The food at Pai reminds me of what I had in weekend markets in Thailand. The interior design is very chic and the restaurant is quite big. I found the interior to be quite different among different sections of the restaurant, which is always fun. 
It's difficult to get in without waiting for a long time for dinner, but I find that if you arrive around 5:30, they can usually accommodate you.
The chicken wings are fantastic! Enjoyed the fresh quality taste. Would recommend for a quick bite !

The atmosphere in this restaurant is modern and clean with an interesting decor. I tried the Khao Soi with beef which our server said was one of the chef's specials. It was egg noodles served in a golden curry broth with crunchy "noodles" on top and chunks of tender beef. The curry was delicious, the noodles were good, and the beef was hearty, ample, and tender. Great satisfying meal.
Good Thai Iced Tea but if you ask for light ice, they'll serve it in a smaller glass. Panang is okay but I've had better. Khao Sol is pretty good. Place has a really small selection of foods.
Delicious food, great service!!! Cozy atmosphere and quick service.  We loved this restaurant and highly recommend making a food stop here!

Pai makes me want to hop on a plane and travel the 500 miles it would take to get from Chicago to Toronto for a good Thai meal. I haven't had such a good Thai meal in as long as I can remember-- at least 6-7 years. The pad thai and the pad gra prow were both so damn good that I couldn't stop myself from eating even after I was full to the point that I was still full 8 hours later. And even at that point, I wanted to return to the restaurant to get more food before we had to hop on the bus to head to Hamilton, our next stop on our vacation. Cocktails here aren't too bad either-- I had the Lowry and the Winter Dog, but what I really wanted was the Tea Mac (or whatever drink it was that had Thai tea in it) but they said they were out of the ingredients.
Service here isn't great-- we had to wave down our server anytime we needed anything and I was so parched for water. Buuuuuuuut the food is so good I'd happily put up with it again.

Tip:-
Utter disappointment-I went by the ratings and didn't read Barbara or Stephanie's reviews-Below average Thai food I guess I have had better.No flavor no kick in the taste?

Best Thai place in Toronto. The location is a little hidden and sign is not that obvious. But the food is awesome. I've tried many items on the menu and never a disappointment. Curry, Khaoi soi, pad thai, pork belly. alll very good

4.5 stars! My husband and I LOVE this place - we eat here usually once a month. We've tried several things on the menu and haven't been really disappointed yet! My favourites are the green curry with chicken (so cute served in a coconut!) and the ox tail ginger curry. Other amazing eats here are the chef nuit pad thai and khao soi with braised beef (noodles in a golden curry sauce). We also like the fried fish (crispy basa fillets) and spring rolls here. Friends always get the braised beef in peanut tamarind sauce (gaeng masaman dish) and the thai iced tea, which are also good.
The pad gra prow (stir fried ground beef with an egg over rice) is also flavourful but doesn't seem worth the $13 price tag since it's so simple to make.
This place is crazy busy all the time but so easy to see why - the food is delicious and quality is amazing. Be prepared to wait an hour or more but it's so worth the wait! The staff are friendly and I love the casual underground atmosphere.
Bonus: they have drinks named after some of the Raptors!
The 0.5 star off is due to the wait to get seated and actually get food (though it's worth it), as well as the cramped seating with not so comfy chairs. If you don't mind these cons much, you'll love this place like we do!

Pai is a difficult restaurant for me to review because the food was hyped up quite a bit prior to my dining experience and my expectations were set higher than normal. Overall it was a very enjoyable experience and I would return back. 
Food: 4 stars - lots of variety, sharing/snack dishes,  good portions, my Khao Soi was very rich and a little too far on the sweet side
Atmosphere: 4.5 stars - very casual/fun, trinkets and odds and ends throughout the restaurant, 
booked well in advance or be prepared to wait for a table
Service: 5 stars - prompt, professional, knowledgable, engaging

Pad Gra Prao.
This is the only dish I eat here now, and with good reason.
Yes it may LOOK simple (rice, fried egg, basil, pork, fish sauce) but I'm not sure why we are not able to replicate this at home. They definitely got some seductive additives in here I swear.
Though the restaurant still gets SO busy during the evening hours, I still say it is better then some of their other competitors down the street. Koh Lipe does have bigger portion and is newer to the scene, but I think Pai still holds a spot in my heart.
Come here and order the Pad Gra Prao. Or fine - order the Khao Soi. Doesn't matter which one you do - you won't go wrong. You can come back to me for an imaginary refund but you definitely won't be needing to!

This might be the best Pad Thai I've ever tasted, and I've had a lot of Pad Thai in my life. They have 5 spice levels, and I got the second spiciest - farang spicy. I loved it, but I definitely needed a lot of water to wash it down as it had quite the kick to it! I would recommend a spice level (or two) down if you don't like it hot. I also tried some of my friend's spring rolls and beef salad which were delicious as well. Highly recommend this place to anyone looking for amazing Thai food in Toronto!

One of the best things I ever ate and I eat a lot of good food. It's been two months since we visited Toronto and I'm still thinking of that night I dined at Pai. The beef in my soup was the most tender flavorful beef I've had.y mouth is watering as I write this review. Everything we had that evening was everything we ever wanted in a Thai restaurant. The cocktails were beautiful and tasty as well. The environment was not what you would expect. It had an underground pub style, which made it a place I wanted to stay an hang out. The couple that opened his place has done an excellent job at making it feel local. Next time I visit Toronto I will make a beeline to this place straight from the airport. Well done Pai!

Pai is a truly authentic Thai place I always like to go to. The vibe is cool and the food tastes great. It's conveniently located in downtown Toronto close to all the major attractions. The service is reasonably fast and attentive given how big this place is.
I honestly can't say anything negative about it and I'm a pretty picky guy. I just like 'em :)
Check 'em out if you're into Thai food and form your own opinion. IMO, Thai food is one of the best in the world along with Japanese, South American and Indian, as long as it's authentic, 'cause there are PLENTY of crappy ethnic restaurants in Toronto.
Worth the hype. Super quick to grab a table, came at a very odd time of the day though - Wednesday at 3PM. The Khao soi was perfect, the Penang was also amazing.

Took a chance around 6:30pm on Sunday without a reservation. Waited in line about 10 minutes and then we were told it would be about 1/2 hour, unless we wanted to sit at the bar. We always enjoy the bar seats so we jumped at it.
An hour later we rolled out, full, happy and aiming to come back!
We started with the garlic shrimp. Well seasoned with a delicious tamarind dipping sauce. We both had the Khao Soi ( one beef, one chicken drumsticks). Incredible depth and richness to the broth. The beef was tender and delicious and the chicken was excellent. The crispy noodles add a great crunch texture. 
The sangria was fantastic. No room for dessert but maybe next time! A fun environment with quick and attentive service.

I mean, the reviews average says it all. Pai is absolutely amazing. Great atmosphere, great location, great food and great service. Cannot really go wrong.
The only frustrating thing about it is actually its popularity. Sometimes the wait can be quite long (despite the good capacity they can accommodate), especially for lunch during work days. My trick: come 11:45am and avoid the 12pm insanity that ensues in trying to get a spot. 
In terms of food, you cannot go wrong with anything on their menu, but I would definitely recommend the khao soi and their pad thai. They also have probably the best spring rolls in the city!
Bon Appétit!

Busy, even on a late Wednesday night, so make reservations. The service was good even if we have to wait a little, they were balancing a lot of customers each. The ambiance is hipster surfer vibe, cool for a fun date. We started with the Northern Thai sausage, which is very good and served with picked veggies and sticky rice, definitely recommend.  The mains came out faster than I thought theu would. I ordered Khao Soi with the beef.  This is a heavy dish and a generous portion.  I have a healthy appetite and I was stuffed. The flavors melded so well, and it was a full bodied taste without having to be spicy. I asked for mild spice. We finished with the mango sticky rice, very good and a solid choice. The service was out of this world and it was my favorite meal of my trip.

We finally got to try Pai after reading lots of good review on it. We had high expectation came in and we definitely weren't disappointed. The portion was decent, 3 people ordered 2 main dishes and 1 salad appetizer, we were all very full after. The sangria was also delicious! We really enjoyed the pad Thai and the green coconut curry! Highly recommended ! 
Another tip: try to get there as early as they open for the day to avoid long waits.

Have been there for 3 times, I have to say I am not a huge fun of Thai style curry, but their pad Thai is amazing! I have tried with chicken one and beef one, I personally love the chicken one a little bit more, since they are softer. 
Mango and sticky rice is a special Thai dessert, really worth to try if you like coconut milk.

Pai is honestly close to a 4.5 stars but for a few real reasons I will stick with a solid 4 stars.I've been to Pai a few times and even bought takeout once. This place really is one of the best Thai food downtown. I haven't had anything I didn't enjoy here so far. 
What I have tried: Khao soi, Chiang Mai beef noodle soup, pad gra prow, pad Thai, and Miang Kung. 
Chiang Mai Beef Noodle Soup: this is probably my favourite at Pai. Comes with nice beef chunks but it is the tangy flavourful beef broth that makes this dish a star. The noodles are flat rice noodles (like pho). This is a must try and is good for sharing as well. 
Pad Thai: you can't go wrong with the classic. It is really delicious as well. Flavours all work perfectly together. 
Khao Soi: probably pai's most popular dish. A very creamy golden curry that is not really that spicy. The crunchy egg noodles are delicious. I personally find it a bit heavy so it is good for sharing or if you can't finish the sauce, doggy bag it and bring it home to have it with rice. 
Pad Gra Prow: flavours are on point, it goes so well with the rice and egg. If you don't like noodles or curry, then this is solid. 
Miang Kung: this is an appetizer where you put a bunch of toppings into betel leaf and eat it together. This needs to be shared as it comes in a big platter - between 3 to 4 people is ideal. It is very refreshing so no worries that it will fill you up. Ingredients are quite simple but everything goes very well together - the pomelo and garlic brings out a nice kick and a very refreshing taste. 
The one down side about this place is it does get very busy so it is difficult to find a table (even on weekdays). You can make reservations but you do have to almost make it one month in advance now. Atmosphere wise is also so-so, it's a bit dark inside which can be nice but it is so noisy so it is quite hard to hold a conversation without yelling across the table. Props though for having hooks for coats near most tables.

Dropped in at Pai on a Tuesday evening and the place was happening! We grabbed some seats at the bar to avoid the wait. Despite the busy crowd, the service was quick, attentive and personal. The drinks and food looked and tasted great. Definitely worth a return visit and now I know to call ahead!
I had the Thai iced tea and the pad thai, my standard go-to for any first visit. They definitely hit the spot in terms of flavour, portion and price. Can't wait to try the other items next time.

This is probably my favorite place to eat in Toronto.  
We found this place on a whim, because we were looking for a place close to where we were, and luckily found parking.  It didnt really look like much from the outside when we passed it but still decided to venture in.  We were really surprised.  It was a small flight of stairs down and we were seated rather quickly since it was still early.  We apparently beat the dinner crowd because by the time we left it was mobbed with a line waiting to get inside.
The menu was quite extensive and we tried a lot of things between the 5 of us.  The food was really good, and varied from traditonal dishes like pad thai and curry to more exotic.  Everything we ordered I would order again.
The service was good too, especially as it got busier, we didnt have any issues with refills or ordering additinal items.
Overall this was a great find and I would definitely go back if I was in the area.  You should give it a try if you are nearby.

First off this place is a total gem. The only downside to this spot was a bit of a slow service, hence the 4 stars but they definitely made up for it. A very cozy ambience and the food was delicious. For starters/apps,  I recommend the spring rolls and the Kung Tawt (garlic shrimp). Also, if you're a fan of spicy food then the Tom Yum Soup will definitely have your mouth scorching, proceed with caution. For the main dish the Chef Nuit Pad Thai or/and the Thai Fried Rice is a MUST!

Took me awhile to come back and let y'all know how amazing this place was. It was our first spot we ate at in Toronto! We were seated at the bar bc this place was poppinnnnn'. Khao Soi was the yummy dish I ordered and still dream of it til' this day. I met my V first Canadian friend, Tiffany, and we've been in touch ever since! The rumors are true, Canadians are hella friendly and Pai is the place to be!

The restaurant is extremely busy. My coworker and I went after work around 5:30 PM and there was already a line up out the door. Once you get to the host, they will give you a buzzer and you can wait by the bar. The restaurant is quite big and we waited about 40 mins before we got seated. The waiters were busy so getting a hold of one got difficult at times but that was understandable. Food was delicious and a reasonable price. We got the Pad Thai, Khao Soi and the Miang Kham. We each got a caesar as well, but that wasn't as good as the food as it had an odd taste.

An authentic Thai restaurant right in the heart of downtown Toronto - near University and King. My daughter and I visited Pai Northern Thai Kitchen on a Wednesday afternoon at around 3:45pm and we were surprised to see how busy it was. When we traveled to Chiang Mai, we stayed at a bed and breakfast run by a woman named Pai and her husband. Pai, in Chiang Mai made some of the most delicious Thai cuisine I have ever encountered. I was hoping for some of the same taste sensations at Pai Northern Thai Kitchen.
The decor is hipster/funky. The atmosphere is loud and slightly aggressive - the music is played at a loud volume. The bathrooms are clean and functional.
While we were seated quickly, we waited a bit for the waitstaff to come to our table so we could order. My daughter and I were not in a rush so the wait wasn't tedious, but I can imagine if you wanted to get on with your day, this wouldn't be the place for a quick meal - largely due to needing to wait to order. Once we did order, our drinks came quickly as well as our food.
My daughter ordered a coconut water. Normally, when we order coconut water at Thai restaurants, it comes in a coconut - which is an added bonus for me, who likes to scoop out the coconut meat. Unfortunately, at Pai's it is served in a glass - the same size glass as water is served. While the size is on the large size, it was disappointing to not have the coconut meat with the coconut water.
My daughter ordered their signature Pad Thai with chicken. She loved it and ate everything on her plate - except the banana leaf. I ordered the tofu with rice and fried egg. I'm beginning to think Toronto loves their salt. It was delicious, but salty. I couldn't put the fish sauce over the rice because it would make the dish much too salty. I usually love the umani taste of the fish sauce over rice. I order the Farang spice level and next time, I'll order the Thai spice level because Farang was way too mild. I had to get more Thai chilies on the side.
We will gladly come back to Pai's in the future. The price point for each dish was pricier than expected, but the quality was fresh and tasty.

This lively Thai restaurant is trendy and very busy. Their customer service is great and the food is top notch. We sat at a floor table on some comfy cushions on the side and had the whole table to ourselves.
I tried the green curry, which comes in a coconut bowl with a side of rice. The dish was rich, flavourful, and just the right amount of spice (slow burn). But like other yelpers, I had a really upset stomach after, so I assumed I got food poisoning. I emailed Pai to let them know and their owner assured me they were looking into it and invited me back for a meal on the house. When we returned, the owner came by our table to check in on us and I was so floored by his attentiveness and the other staff's friendliness.
They think the Thai eggplant in the green curry is causing stomach issues (it's a natural laxative). They've removed the eggplant from the green curry so hopefully that isolates the problem!
Must try: shrimp chips (off the menu) a basket of them comes with oyster sauce
Pad thai (it's the safe option and they make a really good one **fellow cilantro-haters: ask for no cilantro!**
Pass on the mango sticky rice, it was waaaay too sweet.
For the stellar customer service, lively atmosphere and delicious food, I'm sold on Pai.
Great food, fun atmosphere. Reliable spot to take friends from out of town! Always add the fritters to any order.

Awesome restaurant with vibrant energy great selection of authentic Thai food and friendly staff
The owner Jeff 's spirit shows in taste of food, music and sports!

This is one of my favourite restaurants. I highly recommend the Massaman curry, green curry, and Pad Thai. Also the Thai Iced Tea is delicious!
It's a crowded place, however, so be ready to wait a while for a table if you go during prime time. The ambiance is fantastic, although it is a little loud.

it was my last day in Toronto and i really wanted a comfy food so i chose this place. my local buddies agreed that Pai is a must when visiting Toronto. especially if you love Thai food.
so we got here around 12.15PM and it was already packed. we had to wait about 20ish mins for a table which was no biggie at all. we weren't in a rush except that my flight was about 5 hours away. lol
we sat down and ordered a bunch of stuff, we were doing family style.
- Tom Yum Kung - this is an interesting tom yum soup that i have never had before. its sour and refreshing but it was wayyy richer than the one that i am used to in Los Angeles. i would say it was on the heavier end for a soup.
- Moo Ping - i didn't expect them to have this skewer. the marinade was sweet and savory just like one of those marinated short rib that you get on korean bbq restaurant. meat was very tender but $3.5 for a skewer could be a little too much for some people.
- Pad Thai - interesting take of pad thai. really good but not used to seeing this kind of pad thai. it was wetter and darker. for most pad thais, the flavor comes from the tamarind paste but for this particular pad thai, the tamarind flavor was very mild and flavor was mainly from the sauces (oyster sauce, dark soy sauce, i believe these are what they use, i could be wrong)
- Pad Kra Pow with Crispy Pork - i have had better, but theirs weren't too bad. the weakest dish among the 4. 
in short, this isnt the kind of Thai food that i have been exposed to so far. the taste and texture have been adjusted, i can no longer call them authentic Thai food. However, it was really delicious and i enjoyed every single dish that we ordered.
service was great too, food came out pretty fast and she was able to get us everything that we needed.
will i come back? absolutely.

Gluten-free review:
The vast majority of items on the menu here can be made gluten-free and my go-to ones are the Chef Nuit Pad Thai or the Gaeng Masaman. Both are super delicious. Make sure you specify you need your item to be gluten-free though because most aren't normally gluten free. I also recommend getting the thai iced tea if you like the taste of roasted tea.
As for cross contamination, I am not sure how everything is prepared in the kitchen as I didn't ask. I have a moderate intolerance and do not have celiac's disease, however in the numerous times I've been here I've never had a reaction to the food. 
TL;DR most options can be made gluten-free; thai iced tea is yum

Pai is phenomenal.  I was visiting Toronto last weekend and a colleague and I dined here last Thursday night.  
We ordered the plah nua (beef salad) ($14), miang kung (another salad served with the separate components on the dish to be eaten on a betel leaf) ($15), and gaeng kiaw wan (green curry served in a coconut) ($17.50).
It was exceptional.  The perfect meal for my first night ever in Toronto.  I wanted to come back that Sunday for lunch when I was back in Toronto but they do not open until 3pm on Sunday.  
I've eaten Thai food all around the world- it is one of my very favorite cuisines.  And Pai is one of the very best restaurants I have been to.  I can't wait to visit Toronto again; as someone who rarely repeats restaurants because I am always wanting to explore, I am heading back to Pai.
*Thank you to the hostess, for your warm welcome early on and to our wonderful waiter who chatted with us at length and knew it was our first visit to the restaurant and my first visit to Toronto.

A lot of fun, great food, but the noise level was a bit much and made it feel like a place where one scarfs food down and then exits fast.  It's cavernous two, more than 100 seats easily. The papaya salad was great: explosion of flavour in the mouth; we opted for salted crab with ours -- whole pieces, shell and all, which might not be to everyone's taste. The chchirones and prawn crackers that come with the dish are perfect. The best dish was the pork pad gra prow, nicely flavored ground pork with rice and a runny fried egg.  The Khao Soi disappointed:  egg noodles in a very rich, maybe overly rich, lightly curried coconut soup with shrimp (one can also order this with chicken or beef) . Staff were very good, but the ambiance, or utter lack thereof, kills it.  Maybe good for takeout though.  Nice to see they have locally brewed Izumi sake on tap.
Chris Nuttal-Smith more or less nailed it in his Globe review:  
http://www.theglobeandmail.com/life/food-and-wine/restaurant-reviews/with-respect-and-disappointment-pai-northern-thai-kitchen-serves-some-of-the-best-thai-in-toronto/article19970065/

3.5
Pai is hands down my favourite Thai restaurant, and still is. But last night, we were given plates with bits of rice stuck on the top and bottom. So we had to change our plates - hence half star is taken off. 
I had the khao soi with chicken and I think it would've been better if I had it with beef. We waited almost 30 mins for our food to arrive. It was incrediblely busy and I definitely recommend making a reservation! Thai ice tea is also a must when you come here.

Food, music, ambiance was incredible. I'm dining alone and just wanted to eat and roll so I wasn't paying much attention to service til the end when this guy Jonny is so caught up in telling the table next to me that some woman from SNL was there that he hands me the card thing takes it back, I thank HIM and he's just talking to the table and walks away. I initially left 20% but he came back to tell me the card machine was on the fritz so I had to do it again. How fortuitous. 
I gotta assume this place is amazing when the servers aren't star struck. I'll be back

Delicious, authentic, thai food!!! Be careful on how hot you order your food- even the medium spice will burn going down.  
Even though there was a long line out the door on a Saturday night, it moved quickly and we were sat within a few minutes.  Service was friendly and quick.

Tasty?  Yes.
Smaller portions, overhyped, & a few dollars more expensive than a ma&pa place?  Also yes.
Above the decent food, this place survives on buzz and atmosphere.  Subterranean digs is sorta a cross between an island bar/resto.  It is loud, dark, & jammed with knick knacks.
Wait for 2 ppl, on a Wednesday evening, was an hour.  You give the hostess your cell, they give you a pretty accurate estimate, & you'll get a text msg letting you know that your table is ready.  You can respond NO if you've decided to eat elsewhere.  Despite the wait, they've imposed a pretty convenient system, so that was good.
Food took approx. 20mins to arrive (I timed it!), but you sorta don't realise it because it is soo loud.
I ordered the Masaman Beef Curry ($15, I guess they raised the prices as per online menu) and it came in a medium sized soup bowl.  There was maybe 4-5 chunks of brisket, but the rest was a curry soup.  Tasty, but it would've been more fairly priced at $12-13.  Pad Thai tasty good too, but ~$15 and portion was on the adequate, but on the smaller side.  Unlike other Thai places that I've been too, YOU WILL NOT BE TAKING HOME LEFTOVERS if you just order 1 main per person!
There seemed to be a gap after 8pm where, if you're lucky, you can walk in and get a table for a small party.  Otherwise, you'll be waitlisted.
Worth the wait?  If you're up for an experience and never tasted decent Thai food, yes.  Otherwise, you'll survive skipping this one.

I was thoroughly impressed!!! The resturant, just off of Adelaide, is small but got busy really fast on  a Saturday afternoon. I ordered their pad thai with chicken and was happy with how much chicken there was. The sauce on the pad thai was light, yet flavourful with just the right amount of spice. The noodles had great taste and texture. Overall, the pad thai was a great choice and worth trying. The beef curry was also great! The curry wasn't overly spicy and had a depth of flavours from the coconut milk and various spices. As well, the beef was tender and paired well with the rice. We also got the chicken skewers and were quite blown away with the house made sauces; a fish sauce with citrus fruits and a peanut satay, which were both amazing on the tender chicken and on their own. Seriously some of the best Thai food I've ever had, definitely worth checking out!

Food: 4/5
Service: 4/5
Cleanliness: 3.5/5
Atmosphere: 4/5
Price: $$
Getting In
We didn't get to make a reservation beforehand though it is highly, highly recommended that you do so. Our visit to Pai was kind of a spur of the moment thing, as we were originally planning to go for a nice brunch (it was Saturday) at another place before we changed our minds last minute. We decided to try our luck and just entered the restaurant without calling prior to our arrival.
Thankfully, we were able to grab two seats by the bar without much wait. Other than the bar, the majority of the tables were full and we would've had to wait for awhile otherwise.
Ordering
The bartender who also took care of us was really friendly and helpful. As it was our first time here, we had trouble making decisions on the menu - well my hubby did (I was set on Pad Thai, as it's my go to order whenever it's my first visit at a new Thai restaurant). After receiving a couple of recommendations from the bartender, hubby decided to try their Thai fried rice on the lunch menu. I also opted for their coconut water as it's a must order for me in Thai restaurants.
Pad Thai
In my opinion, I have pretty high standards for Pad Thai; I always order it when I can and because I always order it, I tend to compare restaurants and their versions all the time. At Pai, the dish was delicious but it was not as spicy as I would've liked it to be. It also didn't have enough of the fish sauce taste, which is the original sauce used to cook Pad Thai. The dish was more brown in colour than red, perhaps they used more oyster sauce than chili and fish sauce? Overall, the noodles were cooked well and the dish had a wide variety of vegetables and meat, but to me, the original fish sauce was lacking. And I'm right - the menu online says that the pad thai is cooked using the restaurant's house made tamarind sauce and oyster sauce.
Worth ordering? Yes, but it doesn't seem that authentic to me.
Thai Fried Rice
The sauce on the side is fish sauce! Named nam plik nam pla, it is made with fish sauce, garlic, chili and lime. In our opinion, it was a great complement to the fried rice. The fried egg on top was very crispy and well done while keeping the egg yolk still tender, and overall, the fried rice wasn't too overly flavoured. I quite liked that the rice wasn't fried together with the chicken and vegetables so that you could choose how savoury each bite could be. The dish was a little greasy but it's fried rice after all so you can't complain.
Verdict
Overall, our short lunch at Pai was pretty good. Service was great, and I thought that the price of the dishes were well priced as well. Its casual vibe is a hit for most Torontonians, and it really feels like you're in Thailand during your meal as its interior décor is pretty authentic feeling. It's a great restaurant to come with friends and family, colleagues, after work, or even just by yourself for a quick meal at the bar. Can't make it? Try ordering online through their website!

I have literally recommended this place to SO many friends. Hands down my favourite go-to Thai restaurant in Toronto!
Went again tonight (on a gross slushy Wednesday after work). We arrived at 5PM and were able to get seated right away. The restaurant started getting really busy half an hour later. TIP: arrive as early as possible! It often gets busy, even on a weekday!
I've honestly been to this place so many times. My go-to dish is often the green curry. I love that it comes in a coconut with extra sauce on the side. I will always finish that additional bowl of sauce and scoop up every last inch of the insides of the coconut because it's that great! Highly recommend!
I'd also recommend getting the Squash Fritters, Thai Iced Tea and the Pad Gra Prow (with beef). They're all amazingly delicious and I've had a fair share of them in my diet. You simply can't go wrong with Pai!

My sister and I took a long weekend holiday in Toronto in March. We STILL talk about Pai! Everything is amazing. Servers are so friendly and accommodating. Food is fantastic. We went twice we loved it so much.

The food here is amazing but the wait for us to be seated and for us to even get our food was a little too long for my liking.
We were a larger group (6) people and it took us about 45 minutes to get a table. Once seated, the waitress didn't come until about 15 min later. 
I would highly recommend the khao soi and the spring rolls! I got the coconut green curry. It is plated in a coconut which looks very nice but definitely overpriced for the amount of food we got.
Summary: if you have a lot of time, check this place out. If you're starving or in a rush, the dinner rush may not be the best option.

Best Thai food ever! Came here so many times and even got a whole bunch of takeout. 
Pad Gra Pow- Basil was so fragrant and the egg was cooked perfectly 
Chiang Mai Beef Noodle- OMG so tasty! It has a tangy, sweet, spicy, salty  everything in your mouth taste. Beef was also nice and tender. Will always crave this
Chef Nuit Pad Thai- really authentic taste, not too sweet with that nice  tamarind base
Khao Soi- Egg noodles were nice and chewy. The soup was BOMB: creamy, savoury with deep curry flavours without being to overpowering
Go to for Thai food downtown!!

Khao Soi Chicken!! First time falling in love upon the first bite because it was just THAT good. The soup wasn't too spicy and the noodles were so soft, it was such a perfect combo. They were also very generous with the chicken while most places only give a bit when it comes to meat. The chicken was really good at soaking up the soup but I will definitely try beef next time and see how that tastes with the curry. Now all I can think about is Thai food and I can't wait to explore more Thai cuisine!!!

Pai is the best Thai Restaurant in Toronto! So stop reading and go!
If you're still reading, then I might as well tell you why it's the best. The food is authentic, fresh and flavourful. The cocktails are great, and the decor has a really cool vibe that's welcoming yet different at the same time. 
If you're looking for a bit of a different experience, they have 1 Northern Thai style low table where you sit on the ground leaving against triangular pillows. Always a conversation starter!
As for the food, my favorites are the 'Khao Soi', a soupy bowl of curry with meat, egg noodles and crispy fried onions; and the 'Pad Gra Prow', stir fried ground meat topped with a fried egg covered in tasty thai spices. Both are rarely done right and always a good choice at Pai.
Word of caution, everybody knows it the best and therefore, the lines can get ridiculous. So prepare to wait.

Went there on Saturday for lunch, maybe around 11:30/12. They weren't super busy, but had to wait a few minutes for a table. The server said there was a mixup with their delivery and they had a limited menu. We got the Chicken Pad Thai and Khao Soi with Braised Beef. They didn't really have anything else on the menu, which was very disappointing since I wanted to try other things and am from the states. 
Chicken Pad Thai w/ Mild Spice - very good flavor. The chicken in it was good, peanuts were on the side. It was still rather spicy for "mild spice". 
Khao Soi w/ Braised Beef - the curry was very good and so were the noodles. The beef was tender, but super lean, so at times seemed a bit tough. I wish there were more noodles. Could've gotten a side of rice to go with the curry. 
Service was pretty slow. Lots of people standing around, but our server seemed to be everywhere but our table. Waited awhile for our order to be taken then he never came back after our food was served. Had to wave a different person over for water and the check. 
Would like to go back sometime to try other things on their menu...that is if there isn't a "mixup with the delivery order".

FOOD: Delicious and could not stop coming back for more. I've had the Pad Gra Prow that was 10/10 crispy and savoury; the Khao Soi is a staple and the braised beef we had was cooked to mouth-watering textury perfection; the Fried Fish dish was really good and paired well with both spicy and sweet tamarind sauces. 
AMBIENCE: dim, basement bar feel. Rustic, interesting decorations. Hooks along the support beams are useful for making better use of the space.
SERVICE: all smiles and quick and prompt service. No complaints.
PRICE: At a reasonable ~$17 per entree price, Pai is pretty cost-effective for downtown. The meals are large and can certainly fill you. 
TIPS: 
* Come early as there are often lineups
* do not order tea as a $4 is not worth it for flavored water
* Experiment and try different meals here, I'm sure they're all delicious

Definitely a fan of Pai.
We arrived 8 PM on a Saturday, no reservation. A risky situation, only to be made worse by the fact that their kitchen closed early for an event that night (9:30). We were told there was an hour+ wait, and there was a chance we might not get a table even if we waited. 
Being downtown, I probably could've used my time better and went to one of the other billion restaurants in the city, but every single time I've visited Toronto trying to get some khao soi and squash fritters, I've been denied for one reason or another (mostly my fault, I try to go on Sundays like a dumbass when most Thai restaurants are closed). 
WELL NOT TODAY. I drove downtown for some fucking khao soi, I better get some fucking khao soi. So I toughed it out, put my name down, walked around the block several times and returned around 9:20. As luck would have it, they called us for the LAST table they would serve that night. And it was totally worth the wait.
We squeezed our order in and they served it up pretty fast. I inhaled my khao soi. The curry, the noodles, the meat. It was on point. The squash fritters were just OK, they're like less sweet sweet potato fries. I built them up too high in my head after years of drooling at IG pics from places like Khao San Road/Sukho Thai. The khao soi though is the bomb, and that alone is worth a return.

So I would easily rank Pad Thai as one of my favorite foods of all time, which means I tend to order it anytime I spot it on a menu. The Pad Thai at Pai is easily one of the best in the city (if not the best), especially since the demise of the great Khao San Road.
We started with an order of the Spring Rolls ("Deep fried Vegetarian Spring Rolls filled with mushrooms, glass noodles, carrots and sprouts") and they were a cut above, to be sure. They arrived to the table piping hot and accompanied with a tasty dipping sauce. I wouldn't say these were the best spring rolls I've ever had, but they certainly hit the spot.
For my main, I of course went with the Chef Nuit Pad Thai ("Stir fried rice noodle in a home made tamarind sauce with beansprouts, tofu, egg, chives, Thai coriander, fresh lime and home roasted peanuts") and I ordered it Phet Mak Mak (thai spicy). (And they were definitely not kidding around with the spice!)
The dish is plentiful and delicious, and benefits from a seriously impressive layering of flavors. Just when you think you've discovered all the tastes that the dish has to offer, you take another bite that's bursting with flavors you hadn't noticed before. I mean this is a seriously tasty dish.
My one complaint would be that the service wasn't that great. If I'm ordering a plate of food at the spiciest level that you offer, I do expect you to be hovering nearby with a jug of water at all times. (As it was, my small glass was refilled only once.)

Best Thai in town hands down. In downtown Toronto place was packed but we were sat quickly. Definitely not the cheapest but wasn't too steep. Food was very fresh Thai hot was definitely hot like we like. Had the Tom Yum and shrimp/chicken Pad Thai with some Thai wings all very good. The Sangria was very good as well with leechee and pineapples in the pitcher.

The green curry was served in a young coconut which was mostly carved out. Food and cocktails were great. While a little bit more expensive than usual thai places, the environment was fun and cozy. The 90s hip hop, school chairs, and brick walls partitioning the space made the whole place feel like a little hideout.
This place was quite crowded even on a weeknight, so reservations are probably a good idea.

Ahhh one of my favourite Thai restaurants in downtown Toronto! If you're a huge fan of those traditional, flavourful and wonderfully spicy Thai dishes, then this is the place for you. 
Service & Environment
The restaurant is very spacious with ample seating area - they also have a very cute traditional seating area! This place has a casual, relaxed atmosphere with their dimmed lighting and trendy decor. My friend and I came on a Wednesday afternoon and there was no wait time. Like any other restaurant downtown, there isn't free parking space available. You would have to pay around 10-20 bucks to park in one of the parking lots nearby. 
Food
Khao Soi - One of my favourite Thai dishes and this place killed it. Broth was very light and not too creamy and heavy. I thoroughly really enjoyed this dish!
Pad Thai - Very flavourful and perfect amount of sauce. Ratio of noodles to vegetables and meat was also perfect. 
Mango Sticky Rice - I remember trying this last summer and was quite content about it! It was delicous.

A classic case of over hyped expectations is what makes me give this place a 3 star. If i had more tempered expectations it would have been a solid 4. 
I am obviously somewhat spoiled living in Toronto and I now expect to find legit culinary spots that do justice to their roots and can stand up to their counterparts in the homeland. By that test, Pai is decent thai food but i highly doubt it would be more than a local neighborhood spot if it was located in sukhumvit. That said, we only ordered 3-4 dishes from the menu and maybe there were others which might have had a more lasting impression.
Very good Thai food. Very eclectic restaurant. Definitely worth going to for dinner even if you have to wait.
Y'all this place had me in tears! Everything is so good! We all ordered different things and everything was absolutely AMAZING! Please come and try the chicken pad tai! Lawd Jesus! Amazing amazing

I get it, trying to appeal to younger people.. first of all what threw us off about the place was the prices and the that they can make things gluten free. Came to this place because of all the positive reviews. Upon arriving it sounded like a club, dim lighting, loud music.
We shared a Pad Thai and the Khao Pad Thamada ( basically beef fried rice)
The Pad Thai noodles were soggy, I personally enjoy eating noodles with more chew not just falling apart as I pick it up. The flavors were great, I have to say.
The Khao Pad Thamada was mostly rice, and the beef was hard and chewy. 
Overall coming from a family that is part Thai, living in LA with access to authentic Thai food.. wouldn't come back, and thinks this place is over rated and over priced.

Pai is literally my favorite Thai restaurant in downtown Toronto. The ambiance is great, Thai style with some nice Toronto touch (raptors, we the north). 
You can never go wrong with the food here. My favorite is Pad Gra Prow. It is stir fried minced meat on rice. So tasty. I would go with foreigner spicy. Unless you are really really good with spicy,  don't try Thai spicy. I learned my lesson the hard way :P Their chicken wings are very good too. The portion is small though. One order comes with three wings. 
The line can be long during lunch and dinner. They take reservation in advance but not on the same day. 
They also have a party room behind the bar that is perfect for a small party.

This is the TOP restaurant i would recommend to anyone in Toronto. Every single thing we ordered was delicious and the atmosphere was great! We tried the pad gra pow, green curry, pad thai, and the sticky mango rice. We already want to go back and try the rest of the foods on the menu that we didn't get to try!

This is the second most reviewed place in Toronto....had to try right?
Came here on Saturday night before Easter, table for 1 (sad face) around 9pm.  I still had to wait about 40 minutes because it WAS pretty busy,  i didnt even mind the bar!
Service took a bit long but i guess its typical for a saturday night.
All i wanted was pad thai and that was what i ordered!  Intrigued by the level of spice offered,  I asked the server how spicy was the phet mek mek (the spiciest of it all, THAI SPICY is what it was referred) and she said it is like 10 out of 10, like it is really spicy.  I said ok i'll have that with my pad thai.  She asked if i was sure and had a look of concern....ok iim a little worried but they always make it seem really bad, i said im sure.  She said they won't remake it if its too spicy (i guess its my own fault if anything...) i said thats fine... (i started to panicked after she left and texted my friend for moral support)
My plate arrived and it looked pretty...dangerously pretty.  I took my first bite...and...IT BURNNNNNNNNNN....combined with the temperature, it was definitely spicy...i almost teared...but it was DELICIOUSLY BURNING SPICY!!  anyone who loves spicy...enjoys halal guys red sauce...this is the same love feeling!!  
The pad thai is sweet and tangy like pad thai normally is.  The spice mixes well with all the ingredients and the chilies just adds fuel to the delicious fire.  I had this dish with chicken and the chicken was moist and coated with the tamari sauce.  I ate it all up quickly (also so that i could avoid the build up burn!)  
The prices here are decent, maybe just a bit more than most places but converted to USD, its pretty reasonable!  I will definitely come back!

Probably the best place for Thai food in the city and among my favorites. However do keep in mind reservations must be reserved a minimum 24 hrs in advance because this place is ALWAYS busy.
Taking a chance and not making reservations I decided to take JC out for a nice surprise! Fortunately for us, though we did a walk-in and our wait was approximately 30 mins.
The ambiance is cozy with a few funky decor and some Thai related fixtures all over the place. While waiting at the bar for our seats we indulged in a few mini bar eats and drinks they had available:
she had the Tea Ross and I had their plum mule! both were great
For entree we ordered their:
-chicken pad thai and Khoa Soi with Beef: decadent, portions were enough and their prices are reasonable. 5/5
Pad Thai was cooked well, presentable, noodles were spectacularly soft.  Overall excellent dish! 4.5/5

Been here twice in 3 days. Soooo good. 
Very chill ambience with good bar seating. Chill beats set us in the mood as we sunk into our chairs with silly grins on our faces :-D
My wife and I started off with fresh coconut water during both our visits - fresh and flavorful both times! We then proceeded to try the Green Papaya salad (excellent, although the shrimp crackers could have been fresher I think). We then ordered the Garlic Shrimp with Thai chilli sauce (lightly breaded, succulent shrimps, a big hit with us), Pad Thai (well made and full of flavor), Gai Satay (succulent chicken and excellent peanut sauce), Tom Yum soup (heavier on the tomato side than i've been used to in Thailand .... but a huge hit again! It worked very well! A must try.) This was followed by Green Curry in a coconut ....... wow. Just wow. All my 5 senses were involved with this one. Definitely a must try. 
One of the best Thai places we've tried outside of Thailand. I give it 4 stars because I feel they can improve the quality of their shrimp crackers and offer more dishes on their menu. Other than that, loved the place and will definitely be back with more friends and family!

This is probably one of the best thai food restaurants I've ever been to  the food from here is so amazing! I came here on a Wednesday afternoon, about half an hour after opening and there was already a line! I ordered the khao soi, which comes with: egg noodles, golden curry, crispy noodles, your choice of meat (I got the braised beef), coriander, and green onions.

Food tasted really good, the place was packed, the staff was friendly and attentive.
I would recommend calling ahead for a reservation, but walk-ins are welcome.
The spring rolls are to die for!

Favorite pick in Toronto so far. I had the chance to travel in Thailand and the food from Pai was tasting the same (with less spice). The perfect amount of spice, right level of sweet/salty, good portions and fair price. The place is VERY busy we went at 4pm on a Saturday and waited about 20min, definitely worth the wait. I would highly recommend for Asian food fans and will definitely come back.

Interesting below street level pub style restaurant and bar. We came in for dinner and were seated immediately with drink orders taken. I ordered the Panang curry with chicken, a bowl of rice and a side of spring rolls and my wife ordered the chicken satay. Both meals were generous and delicious. The menu however seemed limited for a Thai restaurant but the prices were very reasonable. The service was very friendly, informative and attentive. I would eat here again.
The food here is beyond amazing! Staff are friendly and the buzz is infectious. If you're in Toronto you have to visit no matter the wait!

This place got busy very quickly! We thankfully had a reservation. And they only have a limited amount of seats they reserve as they have a ton of foot traffic. Food was delicious! Service was great. I was told that this was a nice place to take a date but I think its a little too loud. It was hard to hear conversations in the resto. So if you actually want to hear what your date is saying then go elsewhere. However if you want delicious food, with great service, great atmosphere and dont mind if its a little loud then this is the place for you!

This was my favorite meal I have ever had. Don't skip this place. We had the best time.. the establishment runs like a well tuned machine and is very efficient! We had the squash fritters, pad Thai and khao soi and it was delicious! The saki bombs are awesome too, 4 for $20 can't beat that!
I had best  Pad Thai in their location and it's my go to phage when I want to have Asian food
I thought the food seemed pretty authentic. The service was good snd the place was clean

One of the top rated places on Toronto and for good reason! I saw Pai had Khao Soi on the menu being that it's my favorite Thai dish and hard to find in Phoenix I made this a must try. I was with my classmates one  who is vegan and was a little worried that there wouldn't be many options for him, but there were plenty that could be made vegan on the menu. I wasn't expecting much as far as ambiance, but the restaurant was pretty trendy and a cool spot to hang out. They even had tables on the floor with cushions just like Thailand. The Khao Soi was as authentic as it could get, exactly like I had in Thailand. I will definitely return and would highly recommend!

A must visit while in Toronto! If you are a true foodie you will appreciate the quality of detail in the dishes and cocktails. Wings, pork skewers and beef pad Thai was on point. Hands down the best Thai we had in Toronto, do yourself the favor. Enjoy!

okay these people know how to doThai and how to do take out right!
got the Pad Thai and the pork pad graw pow..ordered a papaya salad too.
great flavour.. not heavy and sauce laden ..
have tried their sister resto Sukho Thai which is just as delish!

The food was delicious, ambiance was awesome, and there wasn't much of a wait time. We were sat off to the side, which was much quieter than the main space.
We ordered two entrees and one cocktail. I had the sangria with pineapple and lychee ($11), which was yummy, albeit mostly ice. 
For dinner we had the leaf wraps with shrimp ($15 entree) and a chicken pad Thai. It was not even close to enough food. A small fist-sized pile of noodles and the wraps had 1 tiny shrimp for each, plus minced toppings that amounted to maybe 3 bites total. We left hungry and paid over $50. Plus, we asked for the wraps to come out as an appetizer so we could split both easily, but they came out at the same time to our tiny table, making it very difficult to share.
Rice noodles are cheap! Add some more to fill up your guests!

I love this place. I've never had a bad meal here. Make sure to make reservations. Perhaps the only way you can walk in without one is if you go for dinner at 5pm. 
We always get the grabong (squash fritters, $12.50) to start, and always wish we'd ordered one for each person. The garlic tamarind dip is magic. It's stupidly good. I often get the gaeng masaman with braised beef ($15), as well. I ask for it mild, and I inhale the whole thing far too fast.
The Gaeng Kiaw Wan (served in a coconut, $18) is also really good. You choose the meat you want in the green curry, and you eat it from a coconut. Come on, why are you still reading this? Just go to Pai already.

The food is delicious! The restaurant looks small when you first enter but the dining area is much bigger than expected and there is a ton of seating to the right of the entrance. There is also an area in the back that I think looks like it leads to an outdoor seating area (I haven't sat out there but just by looking around), and it would be perfect for large groups/parties! I've been here a couple of times with friends and the drinks are fantastic and the food is so lovely and flavourful. The price point is also wonderful given the portion sizes. Favourite items: pad gra prow, skewers, beef noodle soup, and the papaya salad.
Also, both of the times I have visited for dinner on a weekday with no reservation but was seated pretty quickly even for a party of four. And their menu can accommodate gluten free and vegan diners too with a ton of options.,  Can't wait to return :)

Pai is good if you order the right dishes and arrive at the right time and on the right day. 
It's extremely busy, which is not my favourite part about the restaurant. This business affects the service, naturally. You won't get water refills when you want them. I've had waiters accidentally spill curry on me while dining there... again, I don't like busy restaurants for a reason. 
Expect to wait over 30 minutes if you arrive after 5 PM. There are tones of amazing Thai restaurants in Toronto. So if it's packed and you have to wait, don't be afraid to try some other spot. I like Si Lom Thai a LOT. 
The food here is catered towards Western preference. It's very, very, very sweet. 
I'm not sure if the cuisine for Pai is less noodle oriented for a reason because I don't really see dish consistency on their menu. Don't expect too many noodle dishes here. 
Of all the dishes I've had, I'd recommend the Penang Curry. It's the best dish on the menu. I've had the Masanang curry, but it was awful one time and great another time. Sometimes the servings are smaller than others. 
The squash fritters are pretty good too. 
There isn't anything else on the menu I'd recommend. The food isn't particularly exceptional, so I'm not sure why it's such a popular spot. 
This restaurant lacks consistency, but on a good night the food is pretty good. I wouldn't jump to recommend Pai, since there are plenty of other amazing spots for Thai in Toronto.

Not like this place needs any more help from my review, but it really is amazing. The flavours are so rich it's near impossible to stop eating. if you're looking to down a bowl of rice - the broths here will make sure that you do. Sure the wait times are long but they do text you when your table is ready so you can explore the surrounding area without worrying about missing your spot in line. 
Be sure to try the squash fritters appy and their Khao Soi dish (IMO the vegan version is better than the original but they're both spectacular). 
Can't wait to come back to try all their other dishes!

I came here over the summer with my friend, and we both really enjoyed the food. Although it was a Wednesday late afternoon there was a huge line! We waited over an hour to get a table. 
However, it was worth it. The foods is amazing. We tried the green curry and pad gra prow. Both were super unique, and the presentation was beautiful. Pai is very different from regular thai places like Salad King, Sukho Thai, and Khao San Road. It has a authentic flavour that is very different and tasty. 
They have excellent vegetarian options, although the portion sizes are small for the price. Will be visiting again soon.

This was our first time in toronto and being Thai decided to look for a Thai restaurant. We found PAI and wow!! 
What can i say other than simply awesome. The food as well as tasting amazing came in huge portions, so it pays to be wise when ordering. Just a quick note, the restaurant ​gets extremely busy so be prepared to wait. But trust me.... Its worth it!
We had dinner here. Tasty food and with a happy atmosphere. Servers were friendly. Many regulars from my observation.

When my brother told me we were going for Thai food, I certainly didn't expect the awesome atmosphere found at Pai! 
Super cool room, lots of awesome decor to take in, like the hand carved Muay Thai Barrel (see pic!) The staff was super friendly and helpful, answering our questions and helping us decide what we wanted to eat (thanks for the great service, Nicole!) 
The food.... oh my. I honestly haven't had such a unique Thai food experience before. My buddy was spot on when he called Pai "extremely hip in comparison to other Thai places."
We had the chicken wings, shrimp, green curry, crispy pork rice, shrimp chips... everything was incredible. Fresh, not too spicy, great textures, brilliant sauces and insanely flavourful noms overall. Even the drinks were amazing... try the Lemongrass Iced Tea and the Thai Iced Tea if you're in the mood for something non-alcoholic!
Really amazing lunch today, thank you Pai, thank you Nicole, and thank you to my brother's friend who said "if you go to Toronto, you have to eat at Pai."

I've been here a few times now and this place never disappoints! Well, aside from the occasional long wait to get a table because it can get pretty full in here... Make sure to reserve your seats ahead of time. 
The atmosphere is so hip and relaxed. Prices and portions are fair. They really try to give you a nice little Thailand feel with the restaurant's neat decor. The coasters for drinks even have elephants on them. So cute. I always order the Chicken Pad Thai because it's my favourite! I absolutely love Thai food and tend to order a Pad Thai wherever I can, and I have to say Pai is one of the best places to get it in Toronto. Lots of flavour that just hits the spot! 
Came here again the other day just to eat and drink with some friends. The food was on point and tasted amazing as usual. We ordered about 7 rounds of soju bombs for the 3 of us (lol)! It comes in a set of 4 shots for $16 - pretty good deal, and didn't taste so bad either. We all had a good time! 
I would DEFINITELY recommend this restaurant if you're into Thai food.

Delicious fresh fantastic!...are the 3 words I would use if only allowed, but seriously this spot is ON POINT...i may easily be back soon...and would go slightly out if the way for a swoop n scoop on some dang dang...some good good, super delicious cuisine at a fair to moderate price

Pai is one of those places I don't mind going to over and over again. The food is great, the vibe is chill, and service is decent. Overall, Pai is a go-to for a good dinner when I don't want fine dining but want some good food.
I usually, without fail, get - Thai Iced Tea, and the Gaeng Masaman with braised beef and/or the Khao Soi with chicken. Both dishes are bursting with flavour and texture. I would also recommend the Grabong as a starter; the fried squash fritters just go well with that dipping sauce. I will admit, I'm a fan of tamarind, which might explain why I enjoy the Grabong sauce and the Gaeng Masaman so much.
I have had some sub-par experiences with some of their other dishes, but as long as I'm ordering what I like, I always enjoy my time (and food) here. 
Overall, I would recommend Pai to anyone looking for a laid back, casual restaurant with delicious food bursting with flavours. It helps that the pricing isn't ridiculously expensive either.

Pai has the best Thai food in the 6ix area! Their Panang beef is super creamy and goes super well with white rice! I also recommend their coconut fried shrimp, it is super light and crispy, and the sweet and sour dipping sauce is the perfect match!
Pai is one of my favourite restaurants in the city.  Grabong, the garlic shrimp, gaeng panag and pad cha hett are my faves.

I've always enjoyed Thai food but Pai has brought it to another level for me! It is a really popular spot, and it was super busy both times we were here for dinner. I've only been here a couple times but I have definitely become a fan. 
So far we had the northern thai sausage platter, green curry with chicken in a coconut, khao soi, gaeng masaman and pad thai. Everything is super delicious but my favourite so far is definitely the khao soi - it's so perfectly creamy! And beware of the green curry - for someone who loves spicy food, the foreigner spice level was almost too spicy! 
The restaurant is a bit dark and it's hard to see what you're eating, but everything is great otherwise.

Best pad Thai I have ever had. Ever. 
Loud inside due to music. Super busy- even at 3 pm.

Okay so I was wrong about this place.
As a huge khao San road fan, I was disappointed over the khao soi I had here a year ago. Since then I have always refused to eat here. In my opinion the khao soi has a too strong coconut flavour.
Today however I got the beef curry and loved it so much! I got it foreign spicy and it was really spicy ! I drank 5 glasses of water to help with the spice levels, but adored the flavours in the curry.
My friends got the pad gra prow, and the beef noodle soup and also enjoyed their meals. For extremely picky eaters, this should say something.
Amazing food, get the skewers? grabbong and khao soi. This place is so good. Also grab a reso hard to walk in cuz it's so popular.

The food here is off the hook! I saw the other reviews and tried to visit but it was too far from my hotel. Luckily, I had a meeting nearby and stopped in for dinner. The atmosphere is cool and the food is delicious. It reminds me of my favorite restaurant in Sydney called Home Thai, which is the best Thai food I have had outside of Thailand and this is a great runner up. 
Whatever you do, plan to go early in your visit to Toronto because you'll be tempted to plan a second trip. I know I wish I could have!

Wow! What a great find on my last night in Toronto. Tired of eating my own cooking, i went on a walk about and found this unassumingly named restaurant with a modest front. I stepped in to find a line waiting a 5:45pm for a seat. The place is in the basement of a larger building and was packed. Once i ate my food i understood why. Balanced flavors with great Thai seasoning and spice. The cool Sapporo beer hit the spot, too.  I ordered the PGB Moo Grob with pan seared and fried pork, jasmine rice, and a large fried egg on top. Make sure you pour the fish sauce on top. Fantastic. Thank you for a great end to my trip!!!!

HOLY. SH**. I'd give this place 10 stars if Yelp had the option. Come here if you want your mind blown away because that's exactly what happened to me. 
I came here super hungover from the night before and had no idea where my friends were taking me for lunch. I was way too hungover to care to even look at the menu so I just told my boyfriend to order for me (which is extremely unlike me). He got me the pad gra prow w/ thai crispy pork and got himself the green curry chicken with noodles. It didn't look like anything special to me so I thought it was just normal thai food. Boy was I wrong. I took my first bite and was SO blown away. I forgot that I was hungover and nauseous and devoured everything. I took my boyfriend's food, I took my friends' food, if I could I would've tried the whole menu. 
All my friends are from Boston and I think we can all agree that we would suffer the 9 hour drive to Toronto just to eat at Pai again. Bravo to the owner(s) and chefs. No thai food will ever taste the same. 
I will be back to Toronto one day just to come here to eat.

Pai is delicious. The staff are pretty friendly for the most part, I understand that it can be stressful at peak hours so I still don't mind giving five stars to Pai. The atmosphere is great, especially if you're into the grunge-y, slightly crowded, and constantly upbeat/loud environment (I love it, personally). I'm never going to stop eating at Pai because it's delicious and serving sizes are big. Prices can be a little high but I think it's totally worth it and a good treat. Till next time, thanks!
One of the best Thai places in Toronto! Try any dish, they are all amazing! I love their pad thai

Food and service were both amazing. Had the authentic taste of northern Thai food and definitely lived up to the hype. Would have personally liked a little more heat in my food, I give it 4 stars because most of the food tends to stay on the savoury sweet side.
